questions.question:
An organization is considering using a new IT service provider. From an audit perspective, which of the
following is the MOST important item to review?

options.A: References from other clients for the service provider
options.B: The physical security of the service provider site
options.C: The proposed service level agreement (SLA) with the service provider
options.D: Background checks of the service provider's employees

justifications.A:
A due diligence activity, such as reviewing references from other clients, is a good practice, but the
service level agreement (SLA) is most critical because it defines what specific levels of performance are
required and makes the provider contractually obligated to deliver what was promised.
justifications.B:
A due diligence activity, such as reviewing physical security controls, is a good practice, but the SLA
is most critical because it defines what specific levels of security are required and makes the provider
contractually obligated to deliver what was promised.
justifications.C:
An SLA is a guarantee that the provider will deliver the services according to the contract When
contracting with a service provider, it is a good practice to enter into an SLA with the provider. The
information systems (IS) auditor will want to ensure that performance and security requirements
are clearly stated in the SLA.
justifications.D:
A due diligence activity, such as the use of background checks fbr the service provider's employees, is a
good practice, but the SLA is most critical because it defines what specific levels of security and labor
practices are required and makes the provider contractually obligated to deliver what was promised.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the function of control self-assessment?

options.A: Quality control
options.B: Quality assessment
options.C: Quality planning
options.D: Quality assurance (QA)

justifications.A:
Quality control can be defined as the part of quality management focused on fulfilling quality
requirements. Quality control procedures monitor and evaluate the resulting service or product.
justifications.B:
Quality assessment is the data collection and analysis through which the degree of conformity to
predetermined standards and criteria are exemplified.
justifications.C:
The role of quality planning is to design a process or service that can meet established goals under
operating conditions.
justifications.D:
Quality assurance (QA) is often achieved by the information systems (IS) auditor serving as a
consultant, advising and facilitating business areas to participate in process improvement and
control. One such approach is through the process of control self-assessment.
243

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing a new outsourcing contract with a service provider would be
MOST concerned if which of the following was missing?

options.A: A clause providing a right to audit the service provider
options.B: A clause defining penalty payments fbr poor performance
options.C: Predefined service level report templates
options.D: A clause regarding supplier limitation of liability

justifications.A:
The absence of a right to audit clause or other forms of attestation that the supplier is compliant
with a certain standard would potentially prevent the information systems (IS) auditor from
investigating any aspect of supplier performance moving forward, including control deficiencies,
poor performance, and adherence to legal requirements. The absence of this clause would be a
major concern for the IS auditor because it would be difficult for the organization to assess whether
the appropriate controls were implemented.
justifications.B:
Although a clear definition of penalty payment terms is desirable, not all contracts require the payment
of penalties fbr poor performance. When performance penalties are required, these penalties are often
subject to negotiation on a case-by-case basis. Therefore, the absence of this information is not as
significant as a lack of right to audit.
justifications.C:
Although the inclusion of service level report templates is desirable, if the requirement for service level
reporting is included in the contract, the absence of predefined templates for reporting is not a significant
concern.
justifications.D:
The absence of a limitation of liability clause for the service provider exposes the provider to unlimited
liability. This is to the advantage of the outsourcing organization so, although the IS auditor might
highlight the absence of such a clause, it does not constitute a major concern.

questions.question:
When reviewing the desktop software compliance of an organization, the information systems (IS) auditor
should be MOST concerned if the installed software:

options.A: is installed, but not documented in the IT department records.
options.B: is being used by users not properly trained in its use.
options.C: is not listed in the approved software standards document.
options.D: has a license that will expire in the next 15 days.

justifications.A:
All software, including licenses, should be documented in IT department records, but this is not as serious
as the violation of policy in installing unapproved software.
justifications.B:
Discovering that users have not been formally trained in the use of a software product is common, and,
although not ideal, most software includes help files and other tips that can assist in learning how to use
the software effectively.
justifications.C:
Installing software not allowed by policy is a serious violation and can put the organization at
security, legal and financial risk. Any software that is allowed should be part of a standard software
list. This is the first thing to review because this would also indicate compliance with policies.
justifications.D:
A software license that is about to expire is not a risk if there is a process in place to renew it.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor of a health care organization is reviewing contractual terms and
conditions of a third-party cloud provider being considered to host patient health information. Which of
the following contractual terms is the GREATEST risk to the customer organization?

options.A: Data ownership is retained by the customer organization.
options.B: The third-party provider reserves the right to access data to perform certain operations.
options.C: Bulk data withdrawal mechanisms are undefined.
options.D: The customer organization is responsible fbr backup, archiving and restoration.

justifications.A: The customer organization would want to retain data ownership and, therefore, this would not be a risk.
justifications.B:
Organizations must review the regulatory environment in which the cloud provider operates
because it may have requirements or restrictions of its own. Some service providers reserve
the right to access customer information (third-party access) to perform certain transactions
and provide certain services. In the case of protected health information, regulations may
restrict certain access. Organizations must then determine whether the cloud provider provides
appropriate controls to ensure data security.
justifications.C:
An organization may eventually wish to discontinue its service with a third-party cloud-based provider.
The organization would then want to remove its data from the system and ensure that the service provider
clears the system (including any backups) of its data. Some providers do not offer automated or bulk
data withdrawal mechanisms, which the organization needs to migrate its data. These aspects should be
clarified prior to using a third-party provider.
justifications.D:
An organization may need to plan its own data recovery processes and procedures if the service provider
does not make this available or the organization has doubts about the service provider's processes. This
would only be a risk if the customer organization could not perform these activities.

questions.question:
Which recovery strategy is MOST appropriate for a business with multiple offices within a region and a
limited recovery budget?

options.A: Hot site maintained by the business
options.B: Commercial cold site
options.C: Reciprocal arrangement between its offices
options.D: Third-party hot site

justifications.A: A hot site maintained by the business would be costly but would provide a high degree of confidence.
justifications.B:
Multiple cold sites leased fbr the multiple offices would lead to an ineffective solution with poor
availability.
justifications.C:
A reciprocal arrangement among its offices would be most appropriate for a business with many
offices within a region. Each office can be designated as a recovery site for some other office. This
would be the least expensive approach and would provide an acceptable level of confidence.
justifications.D:
A traditional hot site provides a third-party facility for recovery. This would be a costly approach
providing a high degree of confidence.
245

questions.question:
During an application audit, an information systems (IS) auditor is asked to provide assurance of the
database's referential integrity. Which of the following should be reviewed?

options.A: Field definition
options.B: Master table definition
options.C: Composite keys
options.D: Foreign key structure

justifications.A: Field definitions describe the table layout but are not directly related to referential integrity.
justifications.B: Master table definition describes the database structure but is not directly related to referential integrity.
justifications.C: Composite keys describe how the keys are created but are not directly related to referential integrity*
justifications.D:
Referential integrity in a relational database refers to consistency between coupled (linked) tables.
Referential integrity is usually enforced by the combination of a primary key or candidate key
(alternate key) and a foreign key. For referential integrity to hold, any field in a table that is
declared a foreign key should contain only values from a parent table's primary key or a candidate
key.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing database security for an organization. Which of the
following is the MOST important consideration for database hardening?

options.A: The default configurations are changed.
options.B: All tables in the database are denormalized.
options.C: Stored procedures and triggers are encrypted.
options.D: The service port used by the database server is changed.

justifications.A:
Default database configurations, such as default passwords and services, need to be changed;
otherwise, the database can be easily compromised by malicious code and by intruders.
justifications.B: The denormalization of a database is related more to performance than to security.
justifications.C:
Limiting access to stored procedures is a valid security consideration but not as critical as changing
default configurations.
justifications.D:
Changing the service port used by the database is a component of the configuration changes that can be
made to the database, but other more critical configuration changes should be made first.

questions.question:
When auditing a database environment, an information systems (IS) auditor will be MOST concerned if the
database administrator (DBA) is performing which of the following fiinctions?

options.A: Performing database changes according to change management procedures
options.B: Installing patches or upgrades to the operating system
options.C: Sizing table space and consulting on table join limitations
options.D: Performing backup and recovery procedures

justifications.A:
Performing database changes according to change management procedures is a normal function of the
database administrator (DBA) and is compliant with the organization's procedures.
justifications.B:
Installing patches or upgrades to the operating system is a function that should be performed by a
systems administrator, not by a DBA. If a DBA is performing this function, there is risk based on
inappropriate separation of duties.
justifications.C:
A DBA is expected to support the business by helping design, create and maintain databases and the
interfaces to the databases.
justifications.D: The DBA often performs or supports database backup and recovery procedures.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST reasonable option fbr recovering a noncritical system?

options.A: Warm site
options.B: Mobile site
options.C: Hot site
options.D: Cold site

justifications.A:
A warm site is generally available at a medium cost, requires less time to become operational and is
suitable for sensitive operations that should be recovered in a moderate amount of time.
justifications.B:
A mobile site is a vehicle ready with all necessary computer equipment that can be moved to any location,
depending upon the need. The need fbr a mobile site relies on the scale of operations.
justifications.C:
A hot site is contracted for a shorter time period at a higher cost, and it is better suited for recovery of
vital and critical applications.
justifications.D:
Generally, a cold site is contracted for a longer period at a lower cost. It is generally used for
noncritical applications because it requires more time to make a cold site operational.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor evaluates the effectiveness of the change management process in an
organization. What is the MOST important control that the IS auditor should look for to ensure system
availability?

options.A: Changes are authorized by IT managers at all times.
options.B: User acceptance testing (UAT) is performed and properly documented.
options.C: Test plans and procedures exist and are closely followed.
options.D: Capacity planning is performed as part of each development project.

justifications.A:
Changes are usually required to be signed off by a business analyst, member of the change control board
or other authorized representatives, not necessarily by IT management.
justifications.B:
User acceptance testing (UAT) is important but not a critical element of change control and does not
usually address the topic of availability as asked in the question.
justifications.C:
The most important control for ensuring system availability is to implement a sound test plan and
procedures that are followed consistently.
justifications.D:
While capacity planning should be considered in each development project, it will not ensure system
availability, nor is it part of the change control process.

questions.question: Data flow diagrams are used by information systems (IS) auditors to:

options.A: identify key controls.
options.B: highlight high-level data definitions.
options.C: graphically summarize data paths and storage.
options.D: portray step-by-step details of data generation.

justifications.A: Identifying key controls is not the fbcus of data flow diagrams. The focus is the flow of data.
justifications.B:
A data dictionary may be used to document data definitions, but the data flow diagram is used to
document how data move through a process.
justifications.C:
Data flow diagrams are used as aids to graph or chart data flow and storage. They trace data from
their origination to their destination, highlighting the paths and storage of data.
justifications.D:
The purpose of a data flow diagram is to track the movement of data through a process and is not
primarily to document or indicate how data are generated.
248 CIS A ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question: Which of the following statements is useful while drafting a disaster recovery plan (DRP)?

options.A: Downtime costs decrease as the recovery point objective (RPO) increases.
options.B: Downtime costs increase with time.
options.C: Recovery costs are independent of time.
options.D: Recovery costs can only be controlled on a short-term basis.

justifications.A:
Downtime costs are not related to the recovery point objective (RPO). The RPO defines the data backup
strategy, which is related to recovery costs rather than to downtime costs.
justifications.B:
Downtime costs一such as loss of sales, idle resources and salaries—increase with time. A disaster
recovery plan (DRP) should be drawn up to achieve the lowest downtime costs possible.
justifications.C:
Recovery costs decrease with the time allowed for recovery. For example, recovery costs to recover
business operations within two days will be higher than recovery costs within seven days. The essence of
an effective DRP is to minimize uncertainty and increase predictability.
justifications.D: With good planning, recovery costs can be predicted and contained.

questions.question:
Although management has stated otherwise, an information systems (IS) auditor has reasons to believe that
the organization is using software that is not licensed. In this situation, the IS auditor should FIRST:

options.A: include the statement from management in the audit report.
options.B: verify that the software is in use through testing.
options.C: include the item in the audit report.
options.D: discuss the issue with senior management because it could have a negative impact on the organization.

justifications.A:
The statement from management may be included in the audit report, but the auditor should
independently validate the statements made by management to ensure completeness and accuracy.
justifications.B:
When there is an indication that an organization might be using unlicensed software, the
information systems (IS) auditor should obtain sufficient evidence before including it in the report.
justifications.C: With respect to this matter, representations obtained from management cannot be independently verified.
justifications.D:
If the organization is using software that is not licensed, the IS auditor must include this in the report
to maintain objectivity and independence, but the IS auditor should verify that this is the case before
presenting it to senior management.
249

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY role of the information systems (IS) auditor in controlling self-assessment programs?

options.A: Assessor
options.B: Participant
options.C: Facilitator
options.D: Manager

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor leads and guides the auditees in assessing their environment by
providing insights about the objectives of controls based on risk assessment.
justifications.B:
The IS auditor is the facilitator, and the management client participates in the control self-assessment
(CSA) program.
justifications.C:
When CSA programs are established, auditors become internal control professionals and
assessment facilitators.
justifications.D:
The business unit managers take responsibility fbr and ownership of internal control systems under their
authority.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST critical element to execute a disaster recovery plan (DRP) effectively?

options.A: Offsite storage of backup data
options.B: Up-to-date list of key disaster recovery contacts
options.C: Availability of a replacement data center
options.D: Clearly defined recovery time objective

justifications.A:
Remote storage of backups is the most critical disaster recovery plan (DRP) element of the items
listed because access to backup data is required to restore systems.
justifications.B: Having a list of key contacts is important but not as important as having adequate data backup.
justifications.C:
A DRP may use a replacement data center or some other solution, such as a mobile site, reciprocal
agreement, or outsourcing agreement.
justifications.D:
Having a clearly defined recovery time objective is especially important for business continuity planning,
but the core element of disaster recovery (the recovery of IT infrastructure and capability) is data backup.

questions.question:
While reviewing the process fbr continuous monitoring of the capacity and performance of IT resources, an
information systems (IS) auditor should PRIMARILY ensure that the process is focused on which of the
following?

options.A: Adequately monitoring service levels of IT resources and services
options.B: Providing data to enable timely planning fbr capacity and performance requirements
options.C: Providing accurate feedback on IT resource capacity
options.D: Properly forecasting performance, capacity and throughput of IT resources

justifications.A:
Continuous monitoring helps to ensure that service level agreements (SLAs) are met, but this is not
the primary fbcus of monitoring. It is possible that even if a system were offline, it would meet the
requirements of an SLA. Therefore, accurate availability monitoring is more important.
justifications.B:
data gained from capacity and performance monitoring is an input to the planning process, the primary
focus is to monitor availability.
justifications.C:
Accurate capacity monitoring of IT resources is a critical element of a continuous monitoring
process.
justifications.D:
Although continuous monitoring helps management to predict likely IT resource capabilities, the more
critical issue is that availability monitoring is accurate.

questions.question:
Which of the following groups is the BEST source of information fbr determining the criticality of application
systems as part of a business impact analysis (BIA)?

options.A: Business processes owners
options.B: IT management
options.C: Senior business management
options.D: Industry experts

justifications.A:
Business process owners have the most relevant information to contribute because the business
impact analysis (BIA) is designed to evaluate criticality and recovery timelines, based on business
needs.
justifications.B:
Although IT management must be involved, it may not be fully aware of the business processes that need
to be protected.
justifications.C:
Although senior management must be involved, it may not be fully aware of the criticality of applications
that need to be protected.
justifications.D:
The BIA depends on the organization's unique business needs, and the advice of industry experts is of
limited value.
251

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing an organization's disaster recovery plan (DRP)
implementation. The project was completed on time and on budget. During the review, the auditor uncovers
several areas of concern. Which of the following presents the GREATEST risk?

options.A: Testing of the DRP has not been performed.
options.B: The disaster recovery strategy does not specify the use of a hot site.
options.C: The business impact analysis (BIA) was conducted, but the results were not used.
options.D: The disaster recovery project manager for the implementation has recently left the organization.

justifications.A:
Although testing a disaster recovery plan (DRP) is a critical component of a successful disaster recovery
strategy, this is not the biggest risk; the biggest risk comes from a plan that is not properly designed.
justifications.B:
The use of a hot site is a strategic determination based on tolerable downtime, cost and other factors.
Although using a hot site may be considered a good practice, this is a very costly solution that may not be
required for the organization.
justifications.C:
The risk of not using the business impact analysis (BIA) results fbr disaster recovery planning
means that the DRP may not be designed to recover the most critical assets in the correct order As
a result, the plan may not be adequate to allow the organization to recover from a disaster
justifications.D:
If the DRP is designed and documented properly, the loss of an experienced project manager should have
minimal impact. The risk of a poorly designed plan that may not meet the requirements of the business is
much more significant than the risk posed by the loss of the project manager.

questions.question:
A vendor released several critical security patches over the past few months, which put a strain on the ability
of the administrators to keep the patches tested and deployed in a timely manner. The administrators asked if
they could reduce the testing of the patches. What approach should the organization take?

options.A: Continue the current process of testing and applying patches.
options.B: Reduce testing and ensure that an adequate back-out plan is in place.
options.C: Delay patching until resources for testing are available.
options.D: Rely on the vendor's testing of the patches.

justifications.A:
Applying security software patches promptly is critical to maintaining the security of the servers;
further, testing the patches is important because the patches may aflect other systems and business
operations. Because the vendor recently released several critical patches in a short time, the
organization may choose to wait to see if this is a temporary problem before making a revision
to policy or procedures.
justifications.B:
Reduced testing increases the risk of business operation disruption due to a faulty or incompatible patch.
Although a back-out plan does help mitigate this risk, a thorough testing up front is the more appropriate
option.
justifications.C:
Applying security software patches promptly is critical to maintaining the security of the servers.
Delaying patching increases the risk of a security breach due to system vulnerability.
justifications.D:
The testing done by the vendor may not be applicable to the systems and environment of the organization
that needs to deploy the patches.

questions.question:
Which of the following issues should be a MAJOR concern to an information systems (IS) auditor who is
reviewing a service level agreement (SLA)?

options.A: A service adjustment resulting from an exception report took a day to implement.
options.B: The complexity of application logs used for service monitoring made the review difficult.
options.C: Key performance indicators (KPIs) were not included in the SLA.
options.D: The document is updated on an annual basis.

justifications.A:
Resolving issues related to exception reports is an operational issue that should be addressed in the
service level agreement (SLA); however, a response time of one day may be acceptable, depending on the
terms of the SLA.
justifications.B: The complexity of application logs is an operational issue, which is not related to the SLA.
justifications.C:
Lack of service measures, such as key performance indicators (KPIs), makes it difficult to gauge the
efficiency and effectiveness of the IT services being provided. Although KPIs can vary based on the
nature of the service and the agreement between parties, commonly included KPIs in SLAs include
response time, uptime, service reliability, etc.
justifications.D:
Although it is important that the document be current, depending on the term of the agreement, it may not
be necessary to change the document more frequently than annually.

questions.question:
During an information systems (IS) audit of the disaster recovery plan of a global enterprise, the auditor
observes that some remote offices have very limited local IT resources. Which of the following observations
is the MOST critical fbr the IS auditor?

options.A:
A test has not been made to ensure that local resources can maintain security and service standards when
recovering from a disaster or incident.
options.B:
The corporate business continuity plan (BCP) plan does not accurately document the systems that exist at
remote offices.
options.C: Corporate security measures have not been incorporated into the test plan.
options.D: A test has not been made to ensure that backups from the remote offices are usable.

justifications.A:
Regardless of the capability of local IT resources, the most critical risk is the lack of testing that
would identify quality issues in the recovery process.
justifications.B:
The corporate business continuity plan (BCP) may not include disaster recovery plan (DRP) details for
remote offices. It is important to ensure that the local plans have been tested.
justifications.C:
Security is an important issue because many controls may be missing during a disaster. However, not
having a tested plan is more important.
justifications.D:
The backups cannot be trusted until they have been tested. However, this should be done as part of the
overall tests of the DRP.
253

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following reports should an information systems (IS) auditor use to check compliance with a
service level agreemenfs requirement for uptime?

options.A: Utilization reports
options.B: Hardware error reports
options.C: System logs
options.D: Availability reports

justifications.A:
Utilization reports document the use of computer equipment, and can be used by management to predict
how, where and/or when resources are required.
justifications.B:
Hardware error reports provide information to aid in detecting hardware failures and initiating corrective
action. These error reports may not indicate actual system uptime.
justifications.C: System logs are used for recording system5s activities. They may not indicate availability.
justifications.D:
information systems (IS) inactivity, such as downtime, is addressed by availability reports. These
reports provide the time periods during which the computer was available for utilization by users
or other processes.

questions.question:
Which of the following would an information systems (IS) auditor use to determine if unauthorized
modifications were made to production programs?

options.A: System log analysis
options.B: Compliance testing
options.C: Forensic analysis
options.D: Analytical review

justifications.A:
System log analysis identifies changes and activity on a system but does not identify whether the change
was authorized unless conducted as a part of a compliance test.
justifications.B:
To determine that only authorized modifications are made to production programs requires the
change management process to be reviewed to evaluate the existence of a trail of documentary
evidence. Compliance testing helps to verify that the change management process has been applied
consistently.
justifications.C: Forensic analysis is a specialized technique for criminal investigation.
justifications.D:
An analytical review assesses the general control environment of an organization.
254 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During a production system change control audit, an information systems (IS) auditor finds that the change
management process is not formally documented and that some migration procedures failed. What should the
IS auditor do next?

options.A: Recommend redesigning the change management process.
options.B: Gain more assurance on the findings through root cause analysis.
options.C: Recommend that program migration be stopped until the change process is documented.
options.D: Document the finding and present it to management.

justifications.A:
Although it may be necessary to redesign the change management process, this cannot be done until a
root cause analysis is conducted to determine why the current process is not being followed.
justifications.B:
A change management process is critical to IT production systems. Before recommending that
the organization take any other action (e.g., stopping migrations or redesigning the change
management process), the information systems (IS) auditor should gain assurance that the incidents
reported are related to deficiencies in the change management process and not caused by some
process other than change management.
justifications.C:
A business relies on being able to make changes when necessary, and security patches must often be
deployed promptly. It is not feasible to halt all changes until a new process is developed.
justifications.D:
The audit results, including the findings of noncompliance, will be delivered to management after a root
cause analysis of the issue has been completed.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor evaluating the resilience of a high-availability network should be MOST
concerned if:

options.A: the setup is geographically dispersed.
options.B: the servers are clustered in one site.
options.C: a hot site is ready for activation.
options.D: diverse routing is implemented fbr the network.

justifications.A: Dispersed geographic locations provide backup if a site has been destroyed.
justifications.B:
A clustered setup in one site makes the entire network vulnerable to natural disasters or other
disruptive events.
justifications.C: A hot site is also a good alternative fbr a single-point-of^foilure site.
justifications.D:
Diverse routing provides telecommunications backup if a network is not available.
255

questions.question:
Management considered two projections fbr its disaster recovery plan (DRP): plan A with two months to fully
recover and plan B with eight months to fully recover. The recovery point objectives (RPOs) are the same in
both plans. It is reasonable to expect that plan B projected higher:

options.A: downtime costs.
options.B: resumption costs.
options.C: recovery costs.
options.D: walk-through costs.

justifications.A:
Because management considered a longer time window fbr recovery in plan B, downtime costs
included in the plan are likely to be higher
justifications.B: Because the recovery time fbr plan B is longer, resumption costs can be expected to be lower.
justifications.C: Because the recovery time fbr plan B is longer, recovery costs can be expected to be lower.
justifications.D: Walk-through costs are not a part of disaster recovery.

questions.question:
Which of the following would an information systems (IS) auditor consider to be MOST helpful when
evaluating the effectiveness and adequacy of a preventive computer maintenance program?

options.A: System downtime log
options.B: Vendor reliability figures
options.C: Regularly scheduled maintenance log
options.D: Written preventive maintenance schedule

justifications.A:
A system downtime log provides evidence regarding the effectiveness and adequacy of computer
preventive maintenance programs. The log is a detective control, but because it is validating the
effectiveness of the maintenance program, it is validating a preventive control.
justifications.B: Vendor reliability figures are not an effective measure of a preventive maintenance program.
justifications.C:

questions.question: Which of the following is widely accepted as one of the critical components in networking management?

the configuration, removing default passwords and possibly hardening the network by disabling
unneeded services.
justifications.B:

important to address issues such as single points of failure and proper network isolation, but it is not the

questions.question:

control as validity.
justifications.B:

important, a system should not accept incorrect values of a password, so a hash total as a control will not

justifications.C:
A validity check is the most useful check for the verification of passwords because it verifies
that the required format has been used—for example, not using a dictionary word and including
nonalphabetical characters. An effective password must have several different types of characters:
alphabetical, numeric and special.
justifications.D:

criteria have been met.

questions.question:
Vendors have released patches fixing security flaws in their software. Which of the following should an

questions.question:
Which of the following controls is MOST effective in ensuring that production source code and object code

questions.question:
During an assessment of software development practices, an information systems (IS) auditor finds that
open-source software components were used in an application designed for a client. What is the GREATEST
concern that the auditor has about the use of open-source software?

options.A: The client did not pay for the open-source software components.
options.B: The organization and client must comply with open-source software license terms.
options.C: Open-source software has security vulnerabilities.
options.D: Open-source software is unreliable fbr commercial use.

justifications.A:
A major benefit of using open-source software is that it is free. The client is not required to pay for the
open-source software components; however, both the developing organization and the client should be
concerned about the licensing terms and conditions of the open source software components that are being
used.
justifications.B:
There are many types of open-source software licenses and each has different terms and conditions.
Some open-source software licensing allows use of the open-source software component freely but
requires that the completed software product must also allow the same rights. This is known
as viral licensing, and if the development organization is not careful, its products can violate
licensing terms by selling the product fbr profit. The information systems (IS) auditor should be
most concerned with open-source software licensing compliance to avoid unintended intellectual
property risk or legal consequences.
justifications.C:
Open-source software, just like any software code, should be tested fbr security flaws and should be part
of the normal system development life cycle (SDLC) process. This is not more of a concern than licensing
compliance.
justifications.D:

reliability and should be part of the normal SDLC process. This is not more of a concern than licensing
compliance.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing database controls discovered that changes to the database

questions.question:
When an organization^ disaster recovery plan (DRP) has a reciprocal agreement, which of the following risk
treatment approaches is being applied?

options.A: Transfer
options.B: Mitigation
options.C: Avoidance
options.D: Acceptance

Risk transfer is the transference of risk to a third party (e.g., buying insurance for activities that pose a
risk).
justifications.B:
A reciprocal agreement in which two organizations agree to provide computing resources to
each other in the event of a disaster is a form of risk mitigation. This usually works well if
both organizations have similar information processing facilities. Because the intended effect of
reciprocal agreements is to have a functional disaster recovery plan (DRP), it is a risk mitigation
strategy.
justifications.C:
Risk avoidance is the decision to cease operations or activities that give rise to a risk. For example,
an organization may stop accepting credit card payments to avoid the risk of credit card information
disclosure.
justifications.D:
Risk acceptance occurs when an organization decides to accept the risk as it is and to do nothing to
mitigate or transfer it.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing an organization's recovery from a disaster in which not all
the critical data needed to resume business operations were retained. Which of the following was incorrectly
defined?

options.A: Interruption window
options.B: Recovery time objective
options.C: Service delivery objective
options.D: Recovery point objective

justifications.A:
The interruption window is defined as the amount of time during which the organization is unable to
maintain operations from the point of failure to the time that the critical services/applications are restored.
justifications.B:
The recovery time objective is determined based on the acceptable downtime in the case of a disruption of
operations.
justifications.C:
The service delivery objective (SDO) is directly related to the business needs. SDO is the level of services
to be reached during the alternate process mode until the normal situation is restored.
justifications.D:
The recovery point objective (RPO) is determined based on the acceptable data loss in the case of
a disruption of operations. RPO defines the point in time from which it is necessary to recover the
data and quantifies, in terms of time, the permissible amount of data loss in the case of interruption.

questions.question: The PRIMARY benefit of an IT manager monitoring technical capacity is to:

options.A: identify the need fbr new hardware and storage procurement.
options.B: determine the future capacity need based on usage.
options.C: ensure that the service level requirements are met.

justifications.B: Determining future capacity is one definite benefit of technical capability monitoring.
justifications.C:
Capacity monitoring has multiple objectives; however, the primary objective is to ensure
compliance with the internal service level agreement between the business and IT.
justifications.D:
IT management is interested in ensuring that systems are operating at optimal capacity, but their primary
obligation is to ensure that IT is meeting the service level requirements of the business.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing an organization's disaster recovery plan (DRP) should
PRIMARILY verify that it is:

options.A: tested every six months.
options.B: regularly reviewed and updated.
options.C: approved by the chief executive officer.

(IS). Three months, or even annually, may be appropriate in different circumstances.
justifications.B:
The plan should be reviewed at appropriate intervals, depending on the nature of the business and
the rate of change of systems and personnel. Otherwise, it may become out-of-date and may no
longer be effective.
justifications.C:
Although the disaster recovery plan (DRP) should receive the approval of senior management, it need
not be the chief executive officer if another executive officer is equally or more appropriate. Fora purely

justifications.D:

questions.question:
There are several methods of providing telecommunication continuity. The method of routing traffic through
split-cable or duplicate-cable facilities is called:

options.A: alternative routing.
options.B: diverse routing.
options.C: long-haul network diversity.
options.D: last-mile circuit protection.

justifications.A:
Alternative routing is a method of routing information via an alternate medium, such as copper cable or
fiber optics. This involves the use of different networks, circuits or end points if the normal network is
unavailable.
justifications.B:
Diverse routing routes traffic through split-cable facilities or duplicate-cable facilities. This can be
accomplished with different and/or duplicate cable sheaths. If different cable sheaths are used, the
cable may be in the same conduit and, therefore, subject to the same interruptions as the cable it is
backing up. The communication service subscriber can duplicate the facilities by having alternate
routes, although the entrance to and from the customer premises may be in the same conduit.
The subscriber can obtain diverse routing and alternate routing from the local carrier, including
dual-entrance facilities. This type of access is time-consuming and costly.
justifications.C:
Long-haul network diversity is a diverse, long-distance network using different packet switching circuits
among the major long-distance carriers. It ensures long-distance access if any carrier experiences a
network failure.
justifications.D:
Last-mile circuit protection is a redundant combination of local carrier T-ls (E-ls in Europe), microwave
and/or coaxial cable access to the local communications loop. This enables the facility to have access
during a local carrier communication disaster. Alternate local-carrier routing is also used.

questions.question: Recovery procedures fbr an information processing facility (IPF) are BEST based on:

options.A: recovery time objective (RTO)
options.B: recovery point objective (RPO)
options.C: maximum tolerable outage (MTO)
options.D: information security policy.

justifications.A:
The recovery time objective (RTO) is the amount of time allowed for the recovery of a business
function or resource after a disaster occurs; the RTO is the desired recovery time frame based on
maximum tolerable outage (MTO) and available recovery alternatives.
justifications.B:

is determined based on the acceptable data loss in case of a disruption of operations. The RPO effectively
quantifies the permissible amount of data loss in case of interruption.
justifications.C:
MTO is the amount of time allowed fbr the recovery of a business function or resource after a disaster
occurs; it represents the time by which the service must be restored before the organization is faced with
the threat of collapse.
justifications.D: An information security policy does not address recovery procedures.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is performing an audit in the data center when the fire alarm begins
sounding. The audit scope includes disaster recovery, so the auditor observes the data center staff respond to
the alarm. Which of the following is the MOST important action for the data center staff to complete in this
scenario?

options.A: Notify the local fire department of the alarm condition.
options.B: Prepare to activate the fire suppression system.
options.C: Ensure all persons in the data center are evacuated.
options.D: Remove all backups from the data center.

justifications.A:
Life safety is always the first priority, and notifying the fire department of the alarm is not typically
necessary because most data center alarms are configured to automatically report to the local authorities.
justifications.B:
Fire suppression systems are designed to operate automatically, and activating the system when staff are
not yet evacuated can create confusion and panic, leading to injuries or even fatalities. Manual triggering
of the system can be necessary under certain conditions, but only after all other data center personnel are
safely evacuated.
justifications.C:
In an emergency, safety of life is always the first priority; therefore, the complete and orderly
evacuation of the facility staff is the most important activity.
justifications.D:
Removal of backups from the data center is not an appropriate action because it can delay the evacuation
of personnel. Most organizations have copies of backups in oflfcite storage to mitigate the risk of data loss
fbr this type of disaster.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that the disaster recovery plan (DRP) for an organization does
not include a critical application hosted in the cloud. Management response states that the cloud vendor is
responsible fbr disaster recovery (DR) and DR-related testing. What is the NEXT course of action fbr the IS
auditor to pursue?

options.A: Plan an audit of the cloud vendor.
options.B: Review the vendor contract to determine its DR capabilities.
options.C: Review an independent auditor's report of the cloud vendor.
options.D: Request a copy of the DRP from the cloud vendor.

justifications.A:
Auditing the cloud vendor is useful; however, this is only useful if the vendor is contractually required to
provide disaster recovery (DR) services.
justifications.B:
DR services can only be expected from the vendor when explicitly listed in the contract with well-
defined recovery time objectives and recovery point objectives. Without the contractual language,
the vendor is not required to provide DR services.
justifications.C:
An independent auditor's report, such as Statements on Standards for Attestation Engagements 16, on DR
capabilities can be reviewed to ascertain the vendor's DR capabilities; however, this is only fruitful if the
vendor is contractually required to provide DR services.
justifications.D:
A copy of DR policies can be requested to review their adequacy; however, this will only be useful if the
vendor is contractually required to provide DR services.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is performing a review of the disaster recovery hot site used by a
financial institution. Which of the following is the GREATEST concern?

options.A: System administrators use shared accounts which never expire at the hot site.
options.B: Disk space utilization data are not kept current.
options.C: Physical security controls at the hot site are less robust than at the main site.
options.D: Servers at the hot site do not have the same specifications as at the main site.

justifications.A:
Although it is not a good practice fbr security administrators to share accounts that do not expire, the
greater risk in this scenario is running out of disk space.
justifications.B:
Not knowing how much disk space is in use and, therefore, how much is needed at the disaster
recovery site can create major issues in the case of a disaster
justifications.C:
Physical security controls are important, and this is a concern, but the more important concern is running
out of disk space. The physical characteristics of the disaster recovery site may call for different controls
that may appear to be less robust than the main site; however, such a risk can be addressed through policy
and procedures or by adding additional personnel if needed.
justifications.D:
If the servers at the hot site are capable of running the programs that are required in a disaster recovery
situation, the precise capabilities of the servers at the hot site is not a major risk. It is necessary to ensure
that software configuration and settings match the servers at the main site, but it is not unusual for newer
and more powerful servers to exist at the main site fbr everyday production use while the standby servers
are less powerful.

questions.question:
When reviewing system parameters, an information systems (IS) auditor's PRIMARY concern should be
that:

options.A: they are set to meet both security and performance requirements.
options.B: changes are recorded in an audit trail and periodically reviewed.
options.C: changes are authorized and supported by appropriate documents.
options.D: access to parameters in the system is restricted.

justifications.A:
The primary concern is to find the balance between security and performance. Recording changes
in an audit trail and periodically reviewing them is a detective control; however; if parameters are
not set according to business rules, monitoring of changes may not be an effective control.
justifications.B: Reviewing changes to ensure that they are supported by appropriate documents is also a detective control.
justifications.C:
If parameters are set incorrectly, the related documentation and the fact that these are authorized does not
reduce the impact.
justifications.D:
Restriction of access to parameters ensures that only authorized staff can access the parameters; however,
if the parameters are set incorrectly, restricting access will still have an adverse impact.

questions.question:
An offsite information processing facility (IPF) with electrical wiring, air conditioning and flooring, but no
computer or communications equipment, is a:

options.A: cold site.
options.B: warm site.
options.C: dial-up site.
options.D: duplicate processing facility.

justifications.B:

selected peripheral equipment—such as disk units, controllers and central processing units— to operate
an information processing facility (IPF).
justifications.C: A dial-up site is used fbr remote access, but not for offsite information processing.
justifications.D:
A duplicate IPF is a dedicated, fully developed recovery site that can back up critical applications.

questions.question: An optimized disaster recovery plan (DRP) fbr an organization should:

questions.question:
A disaster recovery plan (DRP) fbr an organization's financial system specifies that the recovery point

Synchronous updates of the data and standby active systems in a hot site meet the RPO and RTO

hours meets the required RTO.

questions.question:
A financial institution that processes millions of transactions each day has a central communications processor
(switch) fbr connecting to automated teller machines. Which of the following is the BEST contingency plan
for the communications processor?

options.A: Reciprocal agreement with another organization
options.B: Alternate processor in the same location
options.C: Alternate processor at another network node
options.D: Duplex communication links

justifications.A:
Reciprocal agreements make an organization dependent on the other organization and raise privacy,
competition and regulatory issues.
justifications.B:
Having an alternate processor in the same location resolves the equipment problem but is not effective if
the failure is caused by environmental conditions (e.g., power disruption).
justifications.C:
The unavailability of the central communications processor disrupts all access to the banking
network. This can be caused by an equipment, power or communications failure. Having a
duplicate processor in another location that can be used for alternate processing is the best solution.
justifications.D:
The installation of duplex communication links is only appropriate if the failure is limited to the
communication link.

questions.question:
Which of the following provides the BEST evidence of an organization's disaster recovery capability
readiness?

options.A: Disaster recovery plan (DRP)
options.B: Customer references fbr the alternate site provider
options.C: Processes fbr maintaining the DRP
options.D: Results of tests and exercises

justifications.A: Having a plan is important, but a plan cannot be considered effective until it has been tested.
justifications.B:
Customer references may aid in choosing an alternate site provider but will not ensure the effectiveness of
the plan.
justifications.C:
A disaster recovery plan must be kept up-to-date through a regular maintenance and review schedule, but
this is not as important as testing.
justifications.D:
Only tests and exercises demonstrate the adequacy of the plans and provide reasonable assurance of
an organization's disaster recovery capability readiness.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds that database administrators (DBAs) have access to the log location
on the database server and the ability to purge logs from the system. What is the BEST audit recommendation
to ensure that DBA activity is effectively monitored?

options.A: Change permissions to prevent DBAs from purging logs.
options.B: Forward database logs to a centralized log server to which the DBAs do not have access.
options.C: Require that critical changes to the database are formally approved.
options.D: Back up database logs to magnetic media.

justifications.A:
Changing the database administrator (DBA) permissions to prevent DBAs from purging logs may not be
feasible and does not adequately protect the availability and integrity of the database logs.
justifications.B:
To protect the availability and integrity of the database logs, it is most feasible to forward the
database logs to a centralized log server to which the DBAs do not have access.
justifications.C:
Requiring that critical changes to the database are formally approved does not adequately protect the
availability and integrity of the database logs.
justifications.D:
Backing up database logs to magnetic media does not adequately protect the availability and integrity of
the database logs.

questions.question:
While performing a review of a critical third-party application, an information systems (IS) auditor is MOST
concerned with discovering:

options.A: inadequate procedures fbr ensuring adequate system portability.
options.B: inadequate operational documentation fbr the system.
options.C: an inadequate alternate service provider listing.
options.D: an inadequate software escrow agreement.

justifications.A:
Procedures to ensure that systems are developed so that they can be ported to other system platforms help
ensure that the system can continue functioning without affecting the business process if changes to the
infrastructure occur. This is less important than the availability of the software.
justifications.B:
Inadequate operational documentation is a risk but is less significant than the risk of unavailability of the
software.
justifications.C:
Although alternate service providers can be used if a vendor goes out of business, having access to the
source code via a software escrow agreement is more important.
justifications.D:
The inclusion of a clause in the agreement that requires software code to be placed in escrow helps
to ensure that the customer can continue to use the software and/or obtain technical support if a
vendor goes out of business.

questions.question:
Which of the following activities should the business continuity manager perform FIRST after the
replacement of hardware at the primary information processing facility (IPF)?

options.A: Verify compatibility with the hot site.
options.B: Review the implementation report.
options.C: Perform a walk-through of the disaster recovery plan (DRP).
options.D: Update the IT assets inventory .

justifications.A:
Before validating that the new hardware is compatible with the recovery site, the business continuity
manager should update the listing of all equipment and IT assets included in the business continuity plan
(BCP).
justifications.B:
The implementation report is of limited value to the business continuity manager because the equipment
has been installed.
justifications.C: The walk-through of the plan should only be done after the asset inventory has been updated.
justifications.D:
An IT assets inventory is the basic input for the BCP/disaster recovery plan (DRP), and the plan
must be updated to reflect changes in the IT infrastructure.

questions.question:
Which of the following would an information systems (IS) auditor consider to be the MOST important to
review when conducting a disaster recovery audit?

options.A: A hot site is contracted fbr and available as needed.
options.B: A business continuity manual is available and current.
options.C: Insurance coverage is adequate and premiums are current.
options.D: Data backups are performed timely and stored offsite.

justifications.A: A hot site is important, but it is of no use if there are no data backups fbr it.
justifications.B: A business continuity manual is advisable but not most important in a disaster recovery audit.
justifications.C: Insurance coverage should be adequate to cover costs but is not as important as having the data backup.
justifications.D:
Without data to process, all other components of the recovery effort are of no value. Even in the
absence of a plan, recovery efforts of any type would not be practical without data to process.

questions.question:
Which of the following is a continuity plan test that simulates a system crash and uses actual resources to
cost-effectively obtain evidence about the plan's effectiveness?

options.A: Paper test
options.B: Post-test
options.C: Preparedness test
options.D: Walk-through

justifications.A:
A paper test is a walk-through of the plan, involving major players who attempt to determine what might
happen in a particular type of service disruption in the plan's execution. A paper test usually precedes the
preparedness test.
justifications.B:
A post-test is actually a test phase and is comprised of a group of activities, such as returning all resources
to their proper place, disconnecting equipment, returning personnel and deleting all organization data
from third-party systems.
justifications.C:
A preparedness test is a localized version of a fiill test, wherein resources are expended in the
simulation of a system crash. This test is performed regularly on different aspects of the plan
and can be a cost-effective way to gradually obtain evidence about the plan9s effectiveness. It also
provides a means to improve the plan in increments.
justifications.D:
A walk-through is a test involving a simulated disaster situation that tests the preparedness and
understanding of management and staff rather than the actual resources.

questions.question:
While designing the business continuity plan (BCP) for an airline reservation system, the MOST appropriate
method of data transfer/backup at an offsite location is:

options.A: shadow file processing.
options.B: electronic vaulting.
options.C: hard-disk mirroring.
options.D: hot-site provisioning.

justifications.A:
In shadow file processing, exact duplicates of the files are maintained at the same site or at a remote
site. The two files are processed concurrently. This is used fbr critical data files, such as airline
booking systems.
justifications.B:
Electronic vaulting electronically transmits data either to direct access storage, an optical disc or another
storage medium; this is a method used by banks. This method is not usually in real time, unlike a shadow
file system.
justifications.C:
Hard-disk minoring provides redundancy in case the primary hard disk fails. All transactions and
operations occur on two hard disks in the same server.
justifications.D:
A hot site is an alternate site ready to take over business operations within a few hours of any business
interruption and is not a method for backing up data.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST method for determining the criticality of each application system in the
production environment?

options.A: Interview the application programmers.
options.B: Perform a gap analysis.
options.C: Review the most recent application audits.
options.D: Perform a business impact analysis (BIA).

justifications.A:
Interviews with the application programmers provide limited information related to the criticality of the
systems.
justifications.B:
A gap analysis is relevant to system development and project management but does not determine
application criticality.
justifications.C:
The audits may not contain the required information about application criticality or may not have been
done recently.
justifications.D:
A business impact analysis (BIA) gives the impact of the loss of each application. A BIA is
conducted with representatives of the business that can accurately describe the criticality of a
system and its importance to the business.

questions.question:
Code erroneously excluded from a production release was subsequently moved into the production
environment, bypassing normal change procedures. Which of the following choices is of MOST concern
to the information systems (IS) auditor performing a postimplementation review?

options.A: The code was missed during the initial implementation.
options.B: The change did not have change management approval.
options.C: The error was discovered during the postimplementation review.
options.D: The release team used the same change order number.

justifications.A:
Although missing a component of a release is indicative of a process deficiency, it is of more concern that
the missed change was promoted into the production environment without management approval.
justifications.B:
Change management approval of changes mitigates the risk of unauthorized changes being
introduced to the production environment Unauthorized changes might result in disruption of
systems or fraud. It is, therefore, imperative to ensure that each change has appropriate change
management approval.
justifications.C:
Most release/change control errors are discovered during postimplementation review. It is of greater
concern that the change was promoted without management approval after it was discovered.
justifications.D: Using the same change order number is not a relevant concern.

questions.question: A hot site should be implemented as a recovery strategy when the:

options.A: disaster downtime tolerance is low.
options.B: recovery point objective (RPO) is high.
options.C: recovery time objective (RTO) is high.
options.D: maximum tolerable downtime is long.

justifications.A:
Disaster downtime tolerance is the time gap during which the business can accept non-availability
of IT facilities. If this time gap is low, recovery strategies that can be implemented within a short
period of time, such as a hot site, should be used.
justifications.B:
The recovery point objective (RPO) is the earliest point in time at which it is possible to recover the data.
A high RPO means that the process would result in greater losses of data.
justifications.C:
A high recovery time objective (RTO) means that additional time would be available fbr the recovery
strategy, thus making other recovery alternatives—such as warm or cold sites—viable alternatives.
justifications.D:
If the maximum tolerable downtime is long, then a warm or cold site is a more cost-effective solution.

questions.question:
Which of the following stakeholders is the MOST important in terms of developing a business continuity plan
(BCP)?

options.A: Process owners
options.B: Application owners
options.C: Board of directors
options.D: IT management

justifications.A:
Process owners are essential in identifying the critical business functions, recovery times and
resources needed.
justifications.B:
A business continuity plan (BCP) is concerned with the continuity of business processes, while
applications may or may not support critical business processes.
justifications.C:
The board of directors might approve the plan, but they are typically not involved in the details of
developing the BCP.
justifications.D:
IT management identifies the IT resources, servers and infrastructure needed to support the critical

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST efficient and sufficiently reliable way to test the design effectiveness of
a change control process?

options.A: Test a sample population of change requests.
options.B: Test a sample of authorized changes.
options.C: Interview personnel in charge of the change control process.
options.D: Perform an end-to-end walk-through of the process.

justifications.A:
Testing a sample population of changes is a test of compliance and operating effectiveness to ensure that
users submitted the proper documentation/requests. It does not test the effectiveness of the design.
justifications.B:
Testing changes that have been authorized may not provide sufficient assurance of the entire process
because it does not test the elements of the process related to authorization or detect changes that
bypassed the controls.
justifications.C:
Interviewing personnel in charge of the change control process is not as effective as a walk-through of the
change controls process because people may know the process but not follow it.
justifications.D:
Observation is the best and most effective method to test changes to ensure that the process is
effectively designed.

questions.question:
During fieldwork, an information systems (IS) auditor experienced a system crash caused by a security patch
installation. To provide reasonable assurance that this event will not recur, the IS auditor should ensure that:

options.A: only systems administrators perform the patch process during nonbusiness hours.
options.B: the clienfs change management and patching processes have proper controls.
options.C: patches are validated using parallel testing in production.
options.D: an approval process of the patch, including a risk assessment, is developed.

justifications.A:
Although system administrators normally install patches, it is more important that changes be made
according to a formal procedure that includes testing and implementing the change during nonproduction
times.
justifications.B:
The change management process, which includes procedures regarding implementing changes
during production hours, helps to ensure that this type of event does not recur. An information
systems (IS) auditor should review the change management process, including patch management
procedures, to verify that the process has adequate controls and to make suggestions accordingly.
justifications.C:
Although patches normally undergo testing, it is often impossible to test all patches thoroughly. It is more
important that changes are made during nonproduction times and that a backout plan is in place in case of
problems.
justifications.D:
An approval process alone cannot directly prevent this type of incident from happening. There should be a
complete change management process that includes testing, scheduling and approval.

questions.question:
A batch transaction job failed in production; however, the same job returned no issues during user acceptance
testing (UAT). Analysis of the production batch job indicates that it was altered after UAT. What control
provides a mitigation fbr this risk?

options.A: Improve regression test cases.
options.B: Activate audit trails for a limited period after release.
options.C: Conduct an application user access review.
options.D: Implement a segregation/separation of duties (SoD) policy.

Improving the quality of the testing is not applicable in this case, because the more important issue is that

justifications.B:

is that developers have access to the production environment.
justifications.C:
Conducting an application user access review does not identify developers5 access to code because they
are not included in this review.
justifications.D:
To ensure proper segregation/separation of duties (SoD), developers should be restricted to the
development environment only. If code needs to be modified after user acceptance testing, the
process must be restarted in development

questions.question:
An organization completed a business impact analysis (BIA) as part of business continuity planning. The
NEXT step in the process is to develop:

options.A: a business continuity strategy.
options.B: a test and exercise plan.
options.C: a user training program.

justifications.B: The recovery strategy and plan development precede the test plan.
justifications.C: Training can only be developed once the business continuity plan (BCP) is in place.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor performing an application maintenance audit would review the log of

questions.question:
Which of the following assures an enterprise of the existence and effectiveness of internal controls relative to
the service provided by a third party?

options.A: Current service level agreement (SLA)
options.B: Recent independent third-party audit report

justifications.C:
Although a business continuity plan (BCP) is essential, it does not provide assurance related to internal

justifications.D:

questions.question:
When reviewing a disaster recovery plan, an information systems (IS) auditor should be MOST concerned
with the lack of:

options.A: process owner involvement.
options.B: well-documented testing procedures.
options.C: an alternate processing facility.
options.D: a well-documented data classification scheme.

justifications.A:
Process owner involvement is a critical part of the business impact analysis (BIA), which is used to
create the disaster recovery plan. If the information systems (IS) auditor determines that process
owners were not involved, this is a significant concern.
justifications.B:
Although well-documented testing procedures are important, unless process owners are involved there is
no way to know whether the priorities and critical elements of the plan are valid.
justifications.C:
An alternate processing facility may be a requirement to meet the needs of the business; however, such a
decision needs to be based on the BIA.
justifications.D:
A data classification scheme is important to ensure that controls over data are appropriate; however, this
is a lesser concern than a lack of process owner involvement.

questions.question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY critical success factor of a control self-assessment (CSA) program?

Assigning a knowledgeable and experienced information systems (IS) auditor as a facilitator for the CSA
program
options.B: Conducting a meeting with the business unit representatives, including relevant staff and management
options.C: Developing the measures of success for each CSA phase (planning, implementation and monitoring)

justifications.C:
The development of the measures of success for each CSA phase would be after identifying the primary

justifications.D:

questions.question:
Which of the following activities performed by a database administrator (DBA) should be performed by a
different person?

options.A: Deleting database activity logs
options.B: Implementing database optimization tools
options.C: Monitoring database usage
options.D: Defining backup and recovery procedures

justifications.A:
Because database activity logs record activities performed by the database administrator (DBA),
deleting them should be performed by an individual other than the DBA. This is a compensating
control to aid in ensuring an appropriate separation of duties and is associated with the DBA's role.
justifications.B: Implementing database optimization tools is part of the DBA's normal job function.
justifications.C: Monitoring database usage is part of the DBA's normal job function.
justifications.D: Defining backup and recovery procedures is part of the DBA's normal job function.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST reason for integrating the testing of noncritical systems in the disaster
recovery plan (DRP) with the business continuity plan (BCP)?

options.A: To ensure that the DRPs is aligned to the business impact analysis (BIA).
options.B: Infrastructure recovery personnel can be assisted by business subject matter experts.
options.C: The BCPs may assume the existence of capabilities that are not in the DRPs.
options.D: To provide business executives with knowledge of disaster recovery capabilities.

justifications.A:
The disaster recovery plan (DRP) should be aligned with the business impact analysis (BIA); however,
this has no impact on integrating the testing of noncritical systems in the DRPs with the business
continuity plan (BCP).
justifications.B:
Infrastructure personnel will be focused on restoring the various platforms that make up the infrastructure,
and it is not necessary fbr business subject matter experts to be involved.
justifications.C:
The BCPs may assume the existence of capabilities that are not part of the DRPs, such as allowing
employees to work from home during the disaster; however, IT may not have made sufficient
provisions for these capabilities (e.g., they cannot support a large number of employees working
from home). Although the noncritical systems are important, it is possible that they are not part of
the DRPs. For example, an organization may use an online system that does not interface with the
internal systems. If the business function using the system is a critical process, the system should be
tested, and it may not be part of the DRP. Therefore, DRP and BCP testing should be integrated.
justifications.D:
Although business executives may be interested in the benefits of disaster recovery, testing is not the best
way to accomplish this task.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds out-of range data in some tables of a database. Which of the
following controls would BEST avoid this situation?

options.A: Log all table update transactions.
options.B: Implement befbre-and-after image reporting.
options.C: Use tracing and tagging.
options.D: Implement integrity constraints in the database.

justifications.A: Logging all table update transactions is a detective control that would not help avoid invalid data entry.
justifications.B:
Implementing befbre-and-after image reporting is a detective control that would not help avoid the
situation.
justifications.C:
Tracing and tagging are used to test application systems and controls and cannot prevent out-of range
data.
justifications.D:
Implementing integrity constraints in the database is a preventive control because data are checked
against predefined tables or rules, preventing any undefined data from being entered.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that some users installed personal software on their PCs. This
is not explicitly forbidden by the security policy. The BEST approach for an IS auditor is to recommend that
the:

options.A: IT department implement control mechanisms to prevent unauthorized software installation.
options.B: security policy be updated to include the specific language regarding unauthorized software.
options.C: IT department prohibit the download of unauthorized software.
options.D: users obtain approval from an IS manager before installing nonstandard software.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor's obligation is to report on observations noted and make the best
recommendation, which is to address the situation through policy. The IT department cannot implement
controls in the absence of the authority provided through policy.
justifications.B:
Lack of specific language addressing unauthorized software in the acceptable use policy is a
weakness in administrative controls. The policy should be reviewed and updated to address the
issue—and provide authority for the IT department to implement technical controls.
justifications.C:

unauthorized software is established first.

questions.question: The purpose of code signing is to provide assurance that:

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor analyzing the audit log of a database management system (DBMS) finds
that some transactions were partially executed as a result of an error and have not been rolled back. Which of
the following transaction processing features has been violated?

options.B: Isolation
options.C: Durability
options.D: Atomicity

the transaction has not violated integrity rules.
justifications.B:

operations. This prevents two transactions from attempting to access the same data at the same time.
justifications.C: Durability guarantees that a successful transaction will persist and cannot be undone.
justifications.D:
Atomicity guarantees that either the entire transaction is processed or none of it is.
