questions.question:
Business units are concerned about the performance of a newly implemented system. Which of the following
should an information systems (IS) auditor recommend?

options.A: Develop a baseline and monitor system usage.
options.B: Define alternate processing procedures.
options.C: Prepare the maintenance manual.
options.D: Implement the changes users have suggested.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor should recommend the development of a performance baseline
and monitor the system's performance against the baseline to develop empirical data upon which
decisions fbr modifying the system can be made.
justifications.B:
Alternate processing procedures will not alter a system's performance, and no changes should be made
until the reported issue has been examined more thoroughly.
justifications.C: A maintenance manual will not alter a system's performance or address the user concerns.
justifications.D:
Implementing changes without knowledge of the cause(s) for the perceived poor performance may not
result in a more efficient system.

questions.question: The MAIN purpose of service level management (SLM) is to:

options.A: set expectations between users and providers.
options.B: ensure that services are managed to deliver the highest achievable level of availability.
options.C: keep the costs associated with any service at a minimum.
options.D: monitor and report any legal noncompliance to business management.

justifications.A:
The objective of service level management (SLM) is to negotiate, document and manage (i.e.,
provide and monitor) the services in the manner in which the customer requires those services.
justifications.B:
SLM does not necessarily ensure that services are delivered at the highest achievable level of availability
(e.g., redundancy and clustering). Although maximizing availability might be necessary fbr some critical
services, it cannot be applied as a general rule of thumb.
justifications.C:
SLM cannot ensure that costs for all services will be kept at a low or minimum level because costs
associated with a service will directly reflect the customer's requirements.
justifications.D:
Monitoring and reporting legal noncompliance is not a primary objective of SLM.

questions.question:
Which of the following would be a MAJOR concern fbr an information systems (IS) auditor reviewing a
business continuity plan (BCP)?

options.A: The plan is approved by the chief information officer.
options.B: The plan contact lists have not been updated.
options.C: Test results are not adequately documented.
options.D: The training schedule fbr recovery personnel is not included.

justifications.A:

approval authority to the chief information officer. Pragmatically, lack of documenting test results can
have more significant consequences.
justifications.B:
The contact lists are an important part of the business continuity plan (BCP); however, they are not as
important as documenting the test results.
justifications.C:
The effectiveness of a BCP can best be determined through tests. If results of tests are not
documented, then there is no basis for feedback, updates, etc.
justifications.D: If test results are documented, a need for training will be identified and the BCP will be updated.

questions.question:
Which of the following processes will be MOST effective in reducing the risk that unauthorized software on a
backup server is distributed to the production server?

options.A: Manually copy files to accomplish replication.
options.B: Review changes in the software version control system.
options.C: Ensure that developers do not have access to the backup server.
options.D: Review the access control log of the backup server.

justifications.A:
Even if replication is conducted manually with due care, there remains a risk to copying unauthorized
software from one server to another.
justifications.B:
It is common practice for software changes to be tracked and controlled using version control
software. An information systems (IS) auditor should review reports or logs from this system to
identify the software that is promoted to production. Only moving the versions on the version
control system program will prevent the transfer of development or earlier versions.
justifications.C:
If unauthorized code was introduced onto the backup server by developers, controls on the production
server and the software version control system should mitigate this risk.
justifications.D:
Review of the access log will identify staff access or the operations performed; however, it may not
provide enough information to detect the release of unauthorized software.

questions.question:
An organization recently installed a security patch that crashed the production server. To minimize the
probability of this occurring again, an information systems (IS) auditor should:

options.A: apply the patch according to the patch's release notes.
options.B: ensure that a good change management process is in place.
options.C: thoroughly test the patch before sending it to production.
options.D: approve the patch after doing a risk assessment.

justifications.A: The information systems (IS) auditor should not apply the patch. That is an administrator responsibility.
justifications.B:
An IS auditor must review the change management process, including patch management
procedures, and verify that the process has adequate controls and make suggestions accordingly.
justifications.C: Testing of the patch is the responsibility of the development or production support team, not the auditor.
justifications.D: The IS auditor is not authorized to approve a patch. That is a responsibility of a steering committee.

questions.question:
In a relational database with referential integrity, the use of which of the following keys would prevent
deletion of a row from a customer table if the customer number of that row is stored with live orders on the
orders table?

options.A: Foreign key
options.B: Primary key
options.C: Secondary key
options.D: Public key

justifications.A:
In a relational database with referential integrity, the use of foreign keys would prevent events such
as primary key changes and record deletions, resulting in orphaned relations within the database.
justifications.B:
It should not be possible to delete a row from a customer table when the customer number (primary key)
of that row is stored with live orders on the orders table (the foreign key to the customer table). A primary
key works in one table so it is not able to provide/ referential integrity by itself.
justifications.C: Secondary keys that are not foreign keys are not subject to referential integrity checks.
justifications.D: A public key is related to encryption and not linked in any way to referential integrity.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor examining the security configuration of an operating system (OS) should
review the:

options.A: transaction logs.
options.B: authorization tables.
options.C: parameter settings.
options.D: routing tables.

justifications.A:
Transaction logs are used to track and analyze transactions related to an application or system interface,
but that is not the primary source of audit evidence in an operating system (OS) audit.
justifications.B:
Authorization tables are used to verify implementation of logical access controls and will not be of much
help when reviewing control features of an OS.
justifications.C:
Configuration parameters allow a standard piece of software to be customized for diverse
environments and are important in determining how a system runs. The parameter settings should
be appropriate to an organization^ workload and control environment. Improper implementation
and/or monitoring of OSs can result in undetected errors and corruption of the data being
processed, and lead to unauthorized access and inaccurate logging of system usage.
justifications.D:
Routing tables do not contain information about the OS and, therefore, provide no information to aid in
the evaluation of controls.

questions.question:
While reviewing the IT infrastructure, an information systems (IS) auditor notices that storage resources are
continuously being added. The IS auditor should:

options.A: recommend the use of disk mirroring.
options.B: review the adequacy of offsite storage.
options.C: review the capacity management process.
options.D: recommend the use of a compression algorithm.

justifications.C:
Capacity management is the planning and monitoring of computer resources to ensure that
available IT resources are used efficiently and effectively. This looks at capacity from a strategic
viewpoint and allows a plan to forecast and purchase additional equipment in a planned manner.
justifications.D:
Although data compression may save disk space, it can affect system performance. This is not the first
choice—the auditor should recommend more investigation into the increased demand fbr storage before
providing any recommended solutions.

questions.question:
What is the PRIMARY risk of using reciprocal agreements fbr disaster recovery between two business units
in an organization?

options.A: The documents lack legal sufficiency.
options.B: Both entities are vulnerable to the same incident.
options.C: IT systems have non-identical configurations.
options.D: One party experiences more frequent disruptions than the other.

justifications.A:
Inadequate agreements between two business units is a risk, but generally a lesser one than the risk that
both organizations will suffer a disaster at the same time.
justifications.B:
The use of reciprocal disaster recovery is based on the probability that both organizations will not
suffer a disaster at the same time.
justifications.C:
Although incompatible IT systems can create problems, it is a less significant risk than both organizations
suffering from the same disaster at the same time.
justifications.D:
Although one party may use the other's resources more frequently, this can be addressed by contractual
provisions and is not a major risk.

questions.question: When determining the acceptable time period fbr the resumption of critical business processes:

options.A: only downtime costs need to be considered.
options.B: recovery operations should be analyzed.
options.C: both downtime costs and recovery costs need to be evaluated.
options.D: indirect downtime costs should be ignored.

justifications.A:
Downtime costs cannot be looked at in isolation. The quicker information assets can be restored and
business processing resumed, the smaller the downtime costs. However, the expenditure needed to have
the redundant capability that is required to rapidly recover information resources might be prohibitive fbr
nonessential business processes.
justifications.B:
Recovery operations alone do not determine the acceptable time period for the resumption of critical
business processes, and indirect downtime costs should be considered in addition to the direct cash
outflows incurred due to business disruption.
justifications.C:
Downtime costs and recovery costs need to be evaluated in determining the acceptable time period
before the resumption of critical business processes. The outcome of the business impact analysis
should be a recovery strategy that represents the optimal balance.
justifications.D:
The indirect costs of a serious disruption to normal business activity (e.g., loss of customer and supplier
goodwill and loss of market share) may actually be more significant than direct costs over time, thus
reaching the point where business viability is threatened.

questions.question:
The MOST effective audit procedure in determining if unauthorized changes have been made to production
code is to:

options.A: examine the change control system records and trace them forward to object code files.
options.B: review access control permissions operating within the production program libraries.
options.C: examine object code to find instances of changes and trace them back to change control records.
options.D: review change approved designations established within the change control system.

Examining the change control system records can help identify authorized changes, but it may not directly
address the detection of unauthorized changes.
justifications.B:
Reviewing access control permissions can help prevent unauthorized changes, but it may not detect
changes that have already occurred.
justifications.C:
The procedure of examining object code files to establish instances of code changes and tracing
these back to change control system records is a substantive test that directly addresses the risk of
unauthorized code changes.
justifications.D:
Reviewing change approved designations can help identify authorized changes, but it may not directly
detect unauthorized changes.

questions.question:
Which of the following is MOST important fbr an information systems (IS) auditor to verify while

options.A: Data backups are performed on a timely basis.

options.D: Insurance coverage is adequate and premiums are current.

auditor will always be most concerned with human safety.
justifications.B: A recovery site is important fbr business continuity, but life safety is always the first priority.
justifications.C:
The most important element in any business continuity process is the protection of human life. This

questions.question:
The application systems of an organization using open-source software have no single recognized developer

options.B: Review the code and application of available patches.

justifications.B: Code review is possible, but thorough testing is necessary before applying the patches.
justifications.C:

questions.question: During the audit of a database server, which of the following poses the GREATEST security risk?

options.A: The password on the administrator account does not expire.
options.B: Default global security settings fbr the database remain unchanged.
options.C: Old data have not been purged.
options.D: Database activity is not fully logged.

continued use of default settings.
justifications.B:
Default security settings for the database can allow issues such as blank user passwords or
passwords that are the same as the username. This poses the greatest security risk.
justifications.C:
Failure to purge old data may present a performance issue and data management concern but is not an

justifications.D:
Incomplete logging of database activity is a potential risk but not as serious a risk as default settings.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that developers have operator access to the command line of a
production environment operating system. Which of the following controls would BEST mitigate the risk of
undetected and unauthorized program changes to the production environment?

options.A: Commands typed on the command line are logged.
options.B:
Hash keys are calculated periodically for programs and matched against hash keys calculated fbr the most

options.C:
Access to the operating system command line is granted through an access restriction tool with
preapproved rights.
options.D: Software development tools and compilers have been removed from the production environment.

justifications.B: Periodically matching hash keys enables the detection of changes to files.
justifications.C:

developers already have command line access suggests that this control may be bypassed.
justifications.D:
Removing the tools from the production environment may limit the ability to make unauthorized changes,
but it does not address the risk of undetected changes or changes made through other means.

questions.question:
A new application has been purchased from a vendor and is about to be implemented. Which of the following

options.B: Ensuring that vendor default accounts and passwords have been disabled.
options.C: Removing the old copies of the program from escrow to avoid confusion.

Protecting the executable or object code during the implementation process is essential to prevent
compromise, rather than solely focusing on the source code.
justifications.B:
Disabling vendor default accounts and passwords is a critical part of implementing a new
application.
justifications.C:
Because this is a new application, there should not be any problem with older versions in escrow, making

justifications.D:
Although support and maintenance agreements are important, they may not be a key consideration during

questions.question: Doing which of the following during peak production hours can result in unexpected downtime?

justifications.C:

questions.question:
During an HR audit, an information systems (IS) auditor is informed that there is a verbal agreement between
the IT and HR departments about the level of IT services expected. In this situation, what should the IS
auditor do FIRST?

options.A: Postpone the audit until the agreement is documented.
options.B: Report the existence of the undocumented agreement to senior management.
options.C: Confirm the content of the agreement with both departments.
options.D: Draft a service level agreement for the two departments.

justifications.A:
There is no reason to postpone an audit because a service agreement is not documented, unless that is
all that is being audited. The agreement can be documented after it has been established that there is an
agreement in place.
justifications.B:
Reporting to senior management is not necessary at this stage of the audit because this is not a serious
immediate vulnerability.
justifications.C:
An information systems (IS) auditor should first confirm and understand the current practice
before making any recommendations. Part of this is to ensure that both parties agree with the terms
of the agreement.
justifications.D: Drafting a service level agreement is not the IS auditor's responsibility.

questions.question:
A database administrator (DBA) has identified a performance problem with some tables, which can be solved
through denormalization. This situation will increase the risk of:
<

options.B: deadlocks.
options.C: unauthorized access to data.

risk of deadlocks.
justifications.C:
Unauthorized access to data is primarily addressed through access controls and security mechanisms, and
denormalization does not directly impact this risk.
justifications.D:
Denormalization compromises the structure that ensures data integrity, leading to an increased risk
of data inconsistency and loss of data integrity.

questions.question:
Which of the following processes should an information systems (IS) auditor recommend to assist in the
recording of baselines fbr software releases?

options.B: Backup and recovery
options.C: Incident management
options.D: Configuration management

desired criteria.
justifications.B: Backup and recovery of the configuration are important, but not used to create the baseline.
justifications.C:

justifications.D:

questions.question: The BEST method fbr assessing the effectiveness of a business continuity plan (BCP) is to review the:

questions.question:
With respect to business continuity strategies, an information systems (IS) auditor interviews key stakeholders
in an organization to determine whether they understand their roles and responsibilities. The IS auditor is
attempting to evaluate the:

options.A: clarity and simplicity of the business continuity plans (BCPs).
options.B: adequacy of the BCPs.
options.C: effectiveness of the BCPs.
options.D: ability of IS and end-user personnel to respond effectively in emergencies.

understand their roles and responsibilities. When all stakeholders have a detailed understanding
of their roles and responsibilities in the event of a disaster, an IS auditor can deem the business
continuity plan to be clear and simple.
justifications.B:
To evaluate adequacy, the IS auditor should review the plans and compare them to appropriate standards
and the results of tests of the plan.
justifications.C:
To evaluate effectiveness, the IS auditor should review the results from previous tests or incidents. This is
the best determination for the evaluation of effectiveness. An understanding of roles and responsibilities
by key stakeholders will assist in ensuring the BCP is effective.
justifications.D:
To evaluate the response, the IS auditor should review results of continuity tests. This will provide the
IS auditor with assurance that target and recovery times are met. Emergency procedures and employee
training need to be reviewed to determine whether the organization has implemented plans to allow for an
effective response.

questions.question:
During the design of a business continuity plan (BCP), the business impact analysis (BIA) identifies critical
processes and supporting applications. This will PRIMARILY influence the:

options.A: responsibility fbr maintaining the BCP.
options.B: criteria for selecting a recovery site provider.
options.C: recovery strategy.
options.D: responsibilities of key personnel.

justifications.A:
The responsibility fbr maintaining the business continuity plan (BCP) is decided after the selection or
design of the appropriate recovery strategy and development of the plan.
justifications.B:
The criteria fbr selecting a recovery site provider are decided after the selection or design of the
appropriate recovery strategy.
justifications.C:
The most appropriate strategy is selected based on the relative risk level, timelines and criticality
identified in the business impact analysis (BIA).
justifications.D:
The responsibilities of key personnel are decided after the selection or design of the appropriate recovery
strategy during the plan development phase.
304 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During a review of a business continuity plan (BCP), an information systems (IS) auditor noticed that the
point at which a situation is declared to be a crisis has not been defined. The MAJOR risk associated with this
is that:

options.A: response and recovery actions are initiated too early.
options.B: activating the appropriate response and recovery actions are delayed during a crisis.
options.C: crisis situations may be underestimated or overlooked.
options.D: the BCP may become too rigid.

justifications.A:
Without a defined threshold for declaring a crisis, there is a possibility that response and recovery actions
may be initiated prematurely, resulting in unnecessary costs and disruptions. However, the likelihood of
initiating actions too early is not as critical as the risk of delayed response in the absence of a clear crisis
declaration.
justifications.B:
The absence of a clear definition for declaring a situation as a crisis creates the risk of delays
in activating the appropriate response and recovery actions. Without a predefined threshold or
criteria for identifying a crisis, there is uncertainty and potential confusion about when to escalate
the response, mobilize resources and implement critical measures. This can lead to valuable time
being lost, ineffective decision-making, and delays in mitigating the impacts of the crisis.
justifications.C:
In the absence of a defined point fbr declaring a crisis, there is a risk that crisis situations may be
underestimated or overlooked. However, it is not as significant a concern as delayed reactions.
justifications.D:
Without a defined crisis declaration point, there is a risk that the business continuity plan (BCP) may
become too rigid. This can lead to unnecessary delays and inefficiencies in responding to incidents,
because the plan may require adherence to predefined steps without considering the actual severity and
impact of the situation. However, this risk is not as significant as the risk of delayed response.

questions.question:
An organization has just completed its annual risk assessment. Regarding the business continuity plan (BCP),
what should an information systems (IS) auditor recommend as the next step for the organization?

options.A: Review and evaluate the BCP for adequacy.
options.B: Perform a full simulation of the BCP.
options.C: Train and educate employees regarding the BCP.
options.D: Notify critical contacts in the BCP.

justifications.A:
The business continuity plan (BCP) should be reviewed every time a risk assessment is completed
for the organization.
justifications.B:
Performing a simulation should be completed after the BCP has been deemed adequate fbr the
organization.
justifications.C:
Training of the employees should be performed after the BCP has been deemed adequate for the
organization.
justifications.D:
There is no reason to notify the BCP contacts at this time.
305
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
Which of the following database controls ensure that the integrity of transactions is maintained in an online
transaction processing system's database?

options.A: Authentication controls
options.B: Data normalization controls
options.C: Read/write access log controls
options.D: Commitment and rollback controls

justifications.A:
Authentication controls ensure that only authorized personnel can make changes but do not ensure the
integrity of the changes.
justifications.B: Data normalization is not used to protect the integrity of online transactions.
justifications.C: Log controls are a detective control but do not ensure the integrity of the data in the database.
justifications.D:
Commitment and rollback controls are directly relevant to integrity. These controls ensure that
database operations that form a logical transaction unit will be completed entirely or not at all (i.e.,
if, for some reason, a transaction cannot be fully completed, then incomplete inserts/updates/deletes
are rolled back so that the database returns to its pretransition state).

questions.question:
In a small organization, developers may release emergency changes directly to production. Which of the
following will BEST control the risk in this situation?

options.A: Approve and document the emergency changes promptly after release.
options.B:
Implement a segregated environment for production access and restrict developer access outside of
specific time frames.
options.C: Implement a defined emergency change management process that includes secondary approval.
options.D: Implement strict access controls and permissions on the production machine to prevent unauthorized

justifications.A:
It may be appropriate to allow programmers to make emergency changes if they are documented
and approved after the fact.
justifications.B:
Limiting developer access to production within specific time frames may help establish some controls, but
it does not directly address the risk of unauthorized or unapproved emergency changes.
justifications.C:
Obtaining secondary approval before releasing to production is not as critical in an emergency situation as
documenting the changes promptly.
justifications.D:
Disabling the compiler option in the production machine is not directly related to controlling the risk of
emergency changes. It is more focused on preventing unauthorized code modifications. Although access
controls are important, they should be implemented alongside proper change management processes.

questions.question:
Of the following alternatives, the FIRST approach to developing a disaster recovery strategy is to assess
whether:

options.A: all threats can be completely removed.
options.B: a cost-effective, built-in resilience can be implemented.
options.C: the recovery time objective (RTO) can be optimized.
options.D: the cost of recovery can be minimized.

justifications.A: It is impossible to remove all existing and future threats.
justifications.B:
It is critical to initially identify information assets that can be made more resilient to disasters
(e・g.，diverse routing, alternate paths or multiple communication carriers). Preventing a problem is
always better than planning to address a problem when it happens.
justifications.C:
The optimization of the recovery time objective (RTO) comes later in the development of the disaster
recovery strategy.
justifications.D:
Efforts to minimize the cost of recovery come later in the development of the disaster recovery strategy.
307
C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor determined that the IT manager recently changed the vendor that is
responsible fbr performing maintenance on critical computer systems to cut costs. Although the new vendor
is less expensive, the new maintenance contract specifies a change in incident resolution time specified by the
original vendor. Which of the following should be the GREATEST concern to the IS auditor?

options.A: Disaster recovery plans (DRPs) may be invalid and need to be revised.
options.B: Transactional business data may be lost in the event of system failure.
options.C: The new maintenance vendor is not familiar with the organization's policies.
options.D: Application owners were not informed of the change.

justifications.A:
Disaster recovery plans (DRPs) must support the needs of the business, but the greater risk is that
application owners are not aware of the change in resolution time.
justifications.B:
Transactional business data loss is determined by data backup frequency and, consequently, the backup
schedule.
justifications.C:
The vendor must abide by the terms of the contract and those should include compliance with the privacy
policies of the organization, but the lack of application owner involvement is the most important concern.
justifications.D:
The greatest risk of making a change to the maintenance of critical systems is that the change can
have an adverse impact on a critical business process. Although there is a benefit in selecting a less
expensive maintenance vendor, the resolution time must be aligned with the needs of the business.

questions.question:
In the event of a data center disaster, which of the following is the MOST appropriate strategy to enable a
complete recovery of a critical database?

options.A: Daily data backup to a remote site
options.B: Real-time replication to a remote site
options.C: Hard disk mirroring to a local server
options.D: Real-time data backup to the local storage area network

justifications.A: Daily backup recovery can result in the loss of data from a day's work of data.
justifications.B:
With real-time replication to a remote site, data are updated simultaneously in two separate
locations; therefore, a disaster in one site does not damage the information located in the remote
site. This assumes that both sites are not affected by the same disaster.
justifications.C:
Hard disk mirroring to a local server takes place in the same data center and can possibly be affected by
the same disaster.
justifications.D:
Real-time data backup to the local storage area network takes place in the same data center and can
possibly be affected by the same disaster.
308 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: If the recovery time objective (RTO) increases:

options.A: the disaster tolerance increases.
options.B: the cost of recovery increases.
options.C: a cold site cannot be used.
options.D: the data backup frequency increases.

justifications.A:
The longer the recovery time objective (RTO), the higher the disaster tolerance. The disaster
tolerance is the amount of time the business can afford to be disrupted before resuming critical
operations.
justifications.B: The longer the RTO, the lower the recovery cost.
justifications.C:
It cannot be concluded that a cold site is inappropriate; with a longer RTO, the use of a cold site may
become feasible.
justifications.D: RTO is not related to the frequency of data backups; it is related to recovery point objective.

questions.question:
When developing a disaster recovery plan (DRP), what criteria should be considered when determining the
acceptable downtime?

options.A: Annual loss expectancy
options.B: Service delivery objective
options.C: Quantity of orphan data
options.D: Maximum tolerable outage (MTO)

justifications.A:
The acceptable downtime is not determined by the annual loss expectancy (ALE); ALE is related to risk
management calculations, not disaster recovery.
justifications.B:
The service delivery objective is relevant to business continuity, but it is not determined by acceptable
downtime.
justifications.C:
The quantity of orphan data is relevant to business continuity, but it is not determined by acceptable
downtime.
justifications.D:
Recovery time objective (RTO) is determined based on the acceptable downtime in the case of a
disruption of operations. It indicates the maximum tolerable outage (MTO) that an organization
considers to be acceptable before a system or process must resume following a disaster.
309
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
When reviewing an enterprise's preventive maintenance process for systems at a data center, what is the
MOST important practice that should be in place for an information systems (IS) auditor to be able to ensure
that adequate maintenance is being performed on all critical computing, power and cooling systems?

options.A: Proper background checks on all service personnel are conducted.
options.B: Service personnel are escorted at all times when performing their work.
options.C: Maintenance is scheduled during noncritical processing times.
options.D: Verification of maintenance being performed is done independently.

justifications.A:
Although the trustworthiness of the service personnel is important, it is normal practice for these
individuals to be escorted and supervised by the data center personnel. It is also expected that the service
provider performs this background check, not the customer.
justifications.B:
Escorting service personnel is common and a good practice, but the greater risk in this case is if work is
performed during critical processing times.
justifications.C:
The biggest risk to normal operations in a data center is if an incident or mishap were to happen during
critical peak processing times; therefore, it is prudent to ensure that no type of system maintenance is
performed at these critical times.
justifications.D:
Independent verification confirms documented maintenance activities, ensuring their effectiveness
in sustaining critical systems. It provides assurance and detects any maintenance process gaps or
deficiencies.

questions.question:
Which of the following backup techniques is the MOST appropriate when an organization requires extremely
granular data restore points, as defined in the recovery point objective (RPO)?

options.A: Virtual tape libraries
options.B: Disk-based snapshots
options.C: Continuous data backup
options.D: Disk-to-tape backup

justifications.A:
Virtual tape libraries require time to complete the backup, while continuous data backup happens online
(in real time).
justifications.B:
Disk-based snapshots require time to complete the backup and lose some data between the times of the
backup and the failure, while continuous data backup happens online (in real time).
justifications.C:
Recovery point objective (RPO) is based on the acceptable data loss in the case of a disruption. In
this scenario, the organization needs a short RPO and continuous data backup is the best option.
justifications.D:
Disk-to-tape backup requires time to complete the backup, while continuous data backup happens online
(in real time).
310 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: A lower recovery time objective (RTO) results in:

options.A: higher disaster tolerance.
options.B: higher cost.
options.C: reduced system interruptions.
options.D: more permissive data loss.

justifications.A:
Disaster tolerance relates to the length of time that critical business processes can be interrupted. A higher
disaster tolerance allows for a longer outage and, therefore, longer recovery time.
justifications.B:
recovery time objective (RTO) is based on the acceptable down time in case of a disruption of
operations. The lower the RTO, the higher the cost of recovery strategies.
justifications.C:
The lower the disaster tolerance, the narrower the interruption window. The interruption window is the
length of the outage of critical processes.
justifications.D: Permissive data loss relates to recovery point objective (RPO), not disaster tolerance.

questions.question:
During an implementation review of a recent application deployment, it was determined that several incidents
were assigned incorrect priorities and, because of this, failed to meet the business service level agreement
(SLA). What is the GREATEST concern?

options.A: The support model was not approved by senior management.
options.B: The incident resolution of time specified in the SLA is not realistic.
options.C: There are inadequate resources to support the applications.
options.D: The support model was poorly developed and implemented contributing to inaccurate prioritization and

justifications.A:
Although senior management involvement is important, the more critical issue is whether the support
model was not properly developed and implemented.
justifications.B:
Although the incident resolution time specified in the service level agreement (SLA) may not always
be attainable, the more critical issue is whether the support model was not properly developed and
implemented.
justifications.C:
Although adequate support resources are important, the more critical issue is whether the support model
was not properly developed and implemented.
justifications.D:
The greatest concern for the information systems (IS) auditor is that the support model was not
developed and implemented correctly to prevent or react to potential outages. Incidents can cost
the business a significant amount of money and a support model should be implemented with the
project. This should be a step within the system development life cycle (SDLC) and procedures and,
if it is missed on one project, it may be a symptom of an overall breakdown in process.
311
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: What is the BEST backup strategy fbr a large database with data supporting online sales?

options.A: Weekly full backup with daily incremental backup
options.B: Daily full backup
options.C: Clustered servers
options.D: Mirrored hard disks

justifications.A:
Weekly full backup and daily incremental backup is a poor backup strategy fbr online transactions.
Because this system supports online sales, it can be difficult to recreate lost data and this solution may
result in a loss of up to one day's worth of data.
justifications.B:
A full backup normally requires a couple of hours, and, therefore, it can be impractical to conduct a full
backup every day.
justifications.C: Clustered servers provide a redundant processing capability but are not a backup.
justifications.D:
Mirrored hard disks ensure that all data are backed up to more than one disk so that a failure of
one disk will not result in loss of data.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor notes during an audit that an organization's business continuity plan
(BCP) does not adequately address information confidentiality during the recovery process. The IS auditor
should recommend that the plan be modified to include:

options.A: the level of information security required when business recovery procedures are invoked.
options.B: information security roles and responsibilities in the crisis management structure.
options.C: information security resource requirements.
options.D: change management procedures fbr information security that can affect business continuity arrangements.

justifications.A:
Clearly deHne the level of information security required when invoking business recovery
procedures to ensure confidentiality is maintained.
justifications.B:
During a time of crisis, the security needs of the organization may increase because many usual
controls such as segregation/separation of duties (SoD) are missing. Having security roles in the crisis
management plan is important, but that is not the best answer to this scenario.
justifications.C:
Identifying the resource requirements fbr information security, as part of the business continuity plan
(BCP), is important, but it is more important to set out the security levels that are required fbr protected
information.
justifications.D:
Change management procedures can help keep a BCP up to date but are not relevant to this scenario.
312 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During a disaster recovery test, an information systems (IS) auditor observes that the performance of the
disaster recovery site's server is slow. To find the root cause of this, the IS auditor should FIRST review the:

options.A: event error log generated at the disaster recovery site.
options.B: disaster recovery test plan.
options.C: disaster recovery plan (DRP).
options.D: configurations and alignment of the primary and disaster recovery sites.

justifications.A:
If the issue cannot be clarified, the information systems (IS) auditor should then review the event error
log.
justifications.B:
The disaster recovery test plan does not identify any issues related to system performance unless the test
was poorly designed and inefficient, but that would come after checking the configuration.
justifications.C:
Reviewing the disaster recovery plan (DRP) is unlikely to provide any information about system
performance issues.
justifications.D:
Because the configuration of the system is the most probable cause, the IS auditor should review
that first

questions.question:
An organization has a business process with a recovery time objective (RTO) equal to zero and a recovery
point objective (RPO) close to one minute. This implies that the process can tolerate:

options.A: a data loss of up to one minute, but the processing must be continuous.
options.B: a one-minute processing interruption but cannot tolerate any data loss.
options.C: a processing interruption of one minute or more.
options.D: both a data loss and processing interruption longer than one minute.

justifications.A:
The recovery time objective (RTO) measures organization tolerance for downtime, and the recovery
point objective (RPO) measures how much data loss can be accepted.
justifications.B: A processing interruption of one minute exceeds the zero RTO set by the organization.
justifications.C:
A processing interruption of one minute or more exceeds the continuous availability requirements of an
RTO of zero.
justifications.D: An RPO of one minute only allows data loss of one minute.

questions.question:
Which of the following issues should be the GREATEST concern to the information systems (IS) auditor
when reviewing an IT disaster recovery test?

options.A:
Due to the limited test time window, only the most essential systems were tested, and other systems were
tested separately during the rest of the year.
options.B:
During the test, some of the backup systems were defective or not working, causing the test of these
systems to fail.
options.C:
The procedures to shut down and secure the original production site before starting the backup site
required far more time than planned.
options.D: Every year, the same employees perform the test, and the recovery plan documents are not used because

justifications.A: This is not a concern because over the course of the year, all the systems were tested.
justifications.B:
The purpose of the test is to test the backup plan. When the backup systems are not working, then
the plan cannot be counted on in a real disaster This is the most serious problem.
justifications.C:
In a real disaster, there is no need for a clean shutdown of the original production environment because
the first priority is to bring the backup site up.
justifications.D:
A disaster recovery test should test the plan, processes, people and IT systems. Therefore, if the plan is
not used, its accuracy and adequacy cannot be verified. Disaster recovery should not rely on key staff
because a disaster can occur when they are not available. However, the fact that the test works is less
serious than the failure of the systems and infrastructure that the recovery plan counts on. Good practice
rotates different people through the test and ensures that the plan itself is followed and tested.
314 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
What component requires frequent updating to ensure the continued effectiveness of a disaster recovery plan
(DRP)?

options.A: Contact information of key personnel
options.B: Server inventory documentation
options.C: Individual roles and responsibilities
options.D: Procedures for declaring a disaster

justifications.A:
In the event of a disaster, it is important to have a current updated list of personnel who are key to
the operation of the plan.
justifications.B:
Asset inventory is important and should be linked to the change management process of the organization,
but having access to key people may compensate for outdated records.
justifications.C:
Individual roles and responsibilities are important, but, in a disaster, many people can fill different roles
depending on their experience.
justifications.D:
The procedures for declaring a disaster are important because they can affect response, customer
perception and regulatory issues, but not as important as having the right people there when needed.

questions.question:
A live test of a mutual agreement for IT system recovery was carried out, including a four-hour test of
intensive usage by the business units. The test was successful, but gives only partial assurance that the:

options.A: system and the IT operations team can sustain operations in the emergency environment.
options.B: resources and the environment can sustain the transaction load.
options.C: connectivity to the applications at the remote site meets response time requirements.
options.D: workflow of actual business operations can use the emergency system in case of a disaster.

justifications.A:
The applications have been operated intensively, but the capability of the system and the IT operations
team to sustain and support this environment (ancillary operations, batch closing, error corrections, output
distribution, etc.) is only partially tested.
justifications.B: Because the test involved intensive usage, the backup seems to be able to handle the transaction load.
justifications.C: Because users were able to connect to and use the system, the response time must have been satisfactory.
justifications.D:
The live test of the mutual agreement for IT system recovery, including the intensive usage by
business units, only partially ensures that the workflow of actual business operations can use the
emergency system in case of a disaster
315
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important consideration when defining recovery point objectives
(RPOs)?

options.A: Minimum operating requirements
options.B: Acceptable data loss
options.C: Mean time between failures
options.D: Acceptable time fbr recovery

justifications.A: Minimum operating requirements help define recovery strategies.
justifications.B:
Recovery point objectives (RPOs) are the level of data loss/reworking an organization is willing to
accept
justifications.C: Mean time between failures helps define likelihood of system failure.
justifications.D: Recovery time objectives (RTOs) are the acceptable time delay in availability of business operations.

questions.question: To address an organization's disaster recovery requirements, backup intervals should not exceed the:

options.A: service level objective.
options.B: recovery time objective (RTO).
options.C: recovery point objective (RPO).
options.D: maximum acceptable outage (MAO).

justifications.A:
Organizations try to set service level objective to meet established business targets. The resulting time fbr
the service level agreement (SLA) relates to recovery of services, not to recovery of data.
justifications.B:
The recovery time objective (RTO) defines the time period after the disaster in which normal business
functionality needs to be restored.
justifications.C:
Recovery point objective (RPO) defines the point in time to which data must be restored after a disaster to
resume processing transactions. Backups should be performed in a way that the latest backup is no older
than this maximum time frame. If the backups are not done frequently enough, then too much data are
likely to be lost.
justifications.D:
The maximum acceptable outage (MAO) is the maximum amount of system downtime that is
tolerable. It can be used as a synonym for maximum tolerable period of disruption or maximum
allowable downtime. However, the RTO denotes an objective/target, while the MAO constitutes a
vital necessity fbr an organization's survival.
316 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: The FIRST step in the execution of a problem management mechanism should be:

options.A: issue analysis.
options.B: exception ranking.
options.C: exception reporting.
options.D: root cause analysis.

justifications.A: Analysis and resolution are performed after logging and triage have been performed.
justifications.B: Exception ranking can only be performed after the exceptions have been reported.
justifications.C: The reporting of operational issues is normally the first step in tracking problems.
justifications.D:
Root cause analysis is performed after the exceptions have been identified and is not normally the first
part of problem management.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST supports 24/7 availability?

options.A: Daily backup
options.B: Offsite storage
options.C: Mirroring
options.D: Periodic testing

justifications.A:
Daily backup implies that it is reasonable for restoration to take place within a number of hours but not
immediately.
justifications.B: Offsite storage does not, itself, support continuous availability.
justifications.C: Mirroring of critical elements is a tool that facilitates immediate (failover) recoverability.
justifications.D: Periodic testing of systems does not, itself, support continuous availability.

questions.question:
The PRIMARY purpose of implementing redundant array of inexpensive disks (RAID) level 1 in a file server
is to:

options.A: achieve performance improvement.
options.B: provide user authentication.
options.C: ensure availability of data.
options.D: ensure the confidentiality of data.

justifications.A:
redundant array of inexpensive disks (RAID) level 1 does not improve performance. It writes the data to
two separate disk drives.
justifications.B: RAID level 1 has no relevance to authentication.
justifications.C:
RAID level 1 provides disk mirroring. Data written to one disk are also written to another disk.
Users in the network access data on the first disk; if disk one fails, the second disk takes over. This
redundancy ensures the availability of data.
justifications.D:
RAID level 1 does nothing to provide fbr data confidentiality.
317
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important criterion when selecting a location fbr an offsite storage
facility fbr information systems (IS) backup files? The offsite facility must be:

options.A: physically separated from the data center and not subject to the same risk.
options.B: given the same level of protection as that of the computer data center.
options.C: outsourced to a reliable third party.
options.D: equipped with surveillance capabilities.

justifications.A:
It is important that there is an offsite storage location for information systems (IS) files and that it
is in a location not subject to the same risk as the primary data center
justifications.B:
The offsite location may be shared with other organizations and, therefore, have an even higher level of
protection than the primary data center.
justifications.C: An offsite location may be owned by a third party or by the organization itself.
justifications.D: Physical protection is important but not as important as not being affected by the same crisis.

questions.question: If a database is restored using before-image dumps, where should the process begin following an interruption?

options.A: Before the last transaction
options.B: After the last transaction
options.C: At the first transaction after the latest checkpoint
options.D: At the last transaction before the latest checkpoint

justifications.A:
When using before images, it is important to note that the last transaction in the dump may not
have updated the database before the dump was taken.
justifications.B: The last transaction will not have updated the database and must be reprocessed.
justifications.C: Program checkpoints are irrelevant in this situation. Checkpoints are used in application failures.
justifications.D: Program checkpoints are irrelevant in this situation. Checkpoints are used in application failures.

questions.question:
In addition to the backup considerations for all systems, which of the following is an important consideration
in providing backup for online systems?

options.A: Maintaining system software parameters
options.B: Ensuring periodic dumps of transaction logs
options.C: Ensuring grandfother-father-son file backups
options.D: Maintaining important data at an offsite location

justifications.A: Maintaining system software parameters is important for all systems, not just online systems.
justifications.B:
Regular transaction log dumps are vital to preserving timely data in online systems, acting as a
crucial backup to prevent data loss. Given the high activity volume in online systems, the traditional
backup method may not be feasible.
justifications.C: Having generations of backups is a good practice for all systems.
justifications.D:
All backups should consider offsite storage at a location that is accessible but not likely to be affected by
the same disaster.
318 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following disaster recovery testing techniques is the MOST efficient way to determine the
effectiveness of the plan?

options.A: Preparedness tests
options.B: Paper tests
options.C: Full operational tests
options.D: Actual service disruption

justifications.A:
Preparedness tests involve simulation of the entire environment (in phases) at a relatively low cost
and help the team to better understand and prepare for the actual test scenario.
justifications.B:
Paper tests in a walk-through test the entire plan, but there is no simulation and less is learned. It also is
difficult to obtain evidence that the team has understood the test plan.
justifications.C:
Full operational tests require approval from management, are not easy or practical to test in most
scenarios and may trigger a real disaster.
justifications.D: An actual service disruption is not recommended in most cases unless required by regulation or policy.

questions.question:
Online banking transactions are being posted to the database when processing suddenly comes to a halt. The
integrity of the transaction processing is BEST ensured by:

options.A: database integrity checks.
options.B: validation checks.
options.C: input controls.
options.D: database commits and rollbacks.

justifications.A:
Database integrity checks are important to ensure database consistency and accuracy. These include
isolation, concurrency and durability controls, but the most important issue here is atomicity―the
requirement for transactions to complete entirely and commit, or else roll back to the last known good
point.
justifications.B: Validation checks prevent introduction of corrupt data but do not address system failure.
justifications.C: Input controls are important to protect the integrity of input data but do not address system failure.
justifications.D:
Database commits save completed transaction processing, while rollback reverses partially
completed transaction processing if the transaction foils.

questions.question:
Which of the following security measures BEST ensures the integrity of information stored in a data
warehouse?

options.A: Validated daily backups
options.B: Change management procedures
options.C: Data dictionary maintenance
options.D: A read-only restriction

justifications.A:
Backups address availability, not integrity. Validated backups ensure that the backup will work when
needed.
justifications.B:
Adequate change management procedures protect the data warehouse and the systems with which the data
warehouse interfaces from unauthorized changes but are not usually concerned with the data.
justifications.C:
Data dictionary maintenance procedures provide for the definition and structure of data that are input to
the data warehouse. This will not affect the integrity of data already stored.
justifications.D:
Applying read-only restriction to a data warehouse prevents data manipulation, because most of the
data stored there are historical and do not require changes.

questions.question: Which of the following ensures the availability of transactions in the event of a disaster?

options.A: Send hourly backups containing transactions offsite.
options.B: Send daily backups containing transactions offsite.
options.C: Capture transactions to multiple storage devices.
options.D: Transmit transactions offsite in real time.

justifications.A:
Sending hourly backups containing transactions ofifsite is not in real time and, therefore, can result in the
loss of one hour of transactional data.
justifications.B:
Sending daily backups containing transactions offsite is not in real time and, therefore, can result in the
loss of one day's worth of transactional data.
justifications.C: Capturing transactions to multiple storage devices does not ensure availability at an offsite location.
justifications.D:
The only way to ensure the availability of all transactions is to perform a real-time transmission to
an offisite facility.

questions.question:
IT management has decided to install a level 1 redundant array of inexpensive disks (RAID) system in all

options.B: increasing the frequency of onsite backups.
options.C: reinstating the offsite backups.
options.D: establishing a cold site in a secure location.

Upgrading to level 5 RAID does not address the problem of catastrophic failure of the data center housing
all the data.
justifications.B:
Increasing the frequency of onsite backups is not relevant to RAID 1 because all data are being mirrored
already.
justifications.C:
A RAID system, at any level, does not protect against a natural disaster. The problem will not be
alleviated without offsite backups.
justifications.D:

used to store data.

questions.question:
Contractual provisions for a hot, warm or cold site should PRIMARILY cover which of the following
considerations?

options.A: Physical security measures
options.B: Total number of subscribers
options.C: Number of subscribers permitted to use a site at one time
options.D: References by other users

justifications.A:

consideration when choosing a third-party site.
justifications.B:

competitors.
justifications.C:
The contract should specify the number of subscribers permitted to use the site at any one time.
The contract can be written to give preference to certain subscribers.
justifications.D:
The references that other users can provide are a consideration taken before signing the contract; they are
not part of the contractual provisions.

questions.question:
Which of the following reports is the MOST appropriate source of information for an information systems
(IS) auditor to validate that an (internet service provider (ISP)) has been complying with an enterprise service
level agreement fbr the availability of outsourced telecommunication services?

options.A: Downtime reports on the telecommunication services generated by the ISP
options.B: A utilization report of automatic failover services generated by the enterprise
options.C: A bandwidth utilization report provided by the ISP
options.D: Downtime reports on the telecommunication services generated by the enterprise

justifications.A:
The internet service provider (ISP)-generated downtime reports are produced by the same entity that is
being monitored. As a result, it will be necessary to review these reports fbr possible bias and/or errors
against other data.
justifications.B:
The information provided by these reports is indirect evidence of the extent that the backup
telecommunication services were used. These reports may not indicate compliance with the service level
agreement, just that the failover systems had been used.
justifications.C: Utilization reports are used to measure the usage of bandwidth, not uptime.
justifications.D:
The enterprise should use internally generated downtime reports to monitor the service provided
by the ISP and, as available, to compare with the reports provided by the ISP.

questions.question: Integrating the business continuity plan (BCP) into IT project management aids in:

questions.question:
An enterprise uses privileged accounts to process configuration changes fbr mission-critical applications.
Which of the following is the BEST and appropriate control to limit the risk in such a situation?

options.A: Ensure that audit trails are accurate and specific.
options.B: Ensure that personnel have adequate training.
options.C: Ensure that personnel background checks are performed fbr critical personnel.
options.D: Ensure that supervisory approval and review are performed fbr critical changes.

justifications.A: Audit trails are a detective control and, in many cases, can be altered by those with privileged access.
justifications.B:
Staff proficiency is important and good training may be somewhat of a deterrent, but supervisory
approval and review is the best choice.
justifications.C:
Performing background checks is a very basic control and will not effectively prevent or detect errors or

justifications.D:
Supervisory approval and review of critical changes by accountable managers are necessary to
prevent and detect unauthorized changes. They ensure separation of duties and safeguard against
unauthorized attempts by employees.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor observed that multiple applications are hosted on the same server. The
recovery time objective (RTO) for the server is:

options.A: based on the application with the longest RTO.
options.B: based on the application with the shortest RTO.
options.C: based on the mean of each application's RTO.
options.D: independent of the RTO and based on the criticality of the application.

justifications.A:
The longest recovery time objective (RTO) is determined fbr noncritical applications, which does not help
in meeting the objectives for critical systems.
justifications.B:
When several applications are hosted on a server, the server's RTO must be determined by taking
the RTO of the most critical application, which is the shortest RTO.
justifications.C: The mean value is higher than the RTO fbr a critical application.
justifications.D:
Critical applications usually have the shortest RTOs. The RTO of the server cannot be independent of the
application RTO.

questions.question:
During an application audit, the information systems (IS) auditor finds several problems related to corrupt
data in the database. Which of the following is a corrective control that the IS auditor should recommend?

options.A: Define the standards, and closely monitor them for compliance.
options.B: Ensure that only authorized personnel can update the database.
options.C: Establish controls to handle concurrent access problems.
options.D: Proceed with restore procedures.

justifications.A: Establishing standards is a preventive control, and monitoring for compliance is a detective control.
justifications.B: Ensuring that only authorized personnel can update the database is a preventive control.
justifications.C: Establishing controls to handle concurrent access problems is a preventive control.
justifications.D:
Proceeding with restore procedures is a corrective control. Restore procedures can be used to
recover databases to their last-known archived version.

questions.question:
Which of the following scenarios provides the BEST disaster recovery plan (DRP) to implement for critical
applications?

options.A: Daily data backups that are stored offsite and a hot site located 140 km from the main data center.
options.B: Daily data backups that are stored onsite in a fireproof safe.
options.C: Real-time data replication between the main data center and the hot site located 500 m from the main site.
options.D: Daily data backups that are stored offsite with a warm site located 70 km from the main data center.

justifications.A:
The absence of real-time backups may pose a challenge depending on the recovery point objective
(RPO).
justifications.B:
Having data backups is necessary, but not having a replication site would be insufficient fbr the critical
application.
justifications.C:
Depending on the type of disaster, a hot site should normally be located more than 500 meters from the
main facility. Having real-time backups may be the best option, depending on the data RPO.
justifications.D:
A warm site may take days to recover, and, therefore, it may not be a suitable solution.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST indicator of the effectiveness of backup and restore procedures while
restoring data after a disaster?

options.A: Members of the recovery team were available.
options.B: Recovery time objectives (RTOs) were met.
options.C: Inventory of backup media was properly maintained.
options.D: Backup media was completely restored at an alternate site.

justifications.A:
The availability of key personnel does not ensure that backup and restore procedures will work
effectively.
justifications.B:
Effective backup and restore procedures are ensured by meeting recovery time objectives (RTOs),
which are defined during the business impact analysis (BIA) stage with input from business process
owners.
justifications.C: The inventory of the backup media is only one element of the successful recovery.
justifications.D:
The restoration of backup media is a critical success, but only if they were able to be restored within the
time frames set by the RTO.

questions.question:
Which of the following would be the MOST appropriate recovery strategy fora sensitive system with a high
recovery time objective (RTO)?

options.A: Warm site
options.B: Hot site
options.C: Cold site
options.D: Mobile recovery site

justifications.A:
Although a warm site may be a good solution, it is not the most appropriate, because it is more expensive
than a cold site.
justifications.B: A hot site is used for those systems classified as critical that have alow recovery time objective (RTO).
justifications.C:
Sensitive systems having a high RTO can be performed manually at a tolerable cost fbr an extended
period of time. The cold site is the most cost-effective solution for such a system.
justifications.D:
A mobile recovery site is not as cost-effective as a cold site and is not appropriate for systems with high
RTOs.

questions.question:
Which of the following should an incident response team address FIRST after a major incident in an
information processing facility (IPF)?

options.A: Restoration at the facility
options.B: Documentation of the facility
options.C: Containment at the facility
options.D: Monitoring of the facility

justifications.A:
Restoration ensures that the affected systems or services are restored to a condition specified in the restore
point objective. This action will be possible only after containment of the damage.
justifications.B:
Documentation of the facility should be prepared to inform management of the incident; however,
damage must be contained first.
justifications.C:
The first priority (after addressing life safety) is the containment of the incident at the facility so
that spread of the damage is minimized. The incident team must gain control of the situation.
justifications.D:
Monitoring of the facility is important, although containment must take priority to avoid spread of the
damage.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that some hard drives disposed of by an enterprise were
not sanitized in a manner that would reasonably ensure that the data cannot be recovered. In addition, the

options.B: determine the sensitivity of the information on the hard drives.
options.C: discuss with the IT manager good practices in data disposal.
options.D: develop an appropriate data disposal policy fbr the enterprise.

justifications.B:
Although a policy is not available, the information systems (IS) auditor should determine the nature
of the information on the hard drives to quantify, as much as possible, the risk.
justifications.C:
It would be premature to discuss good practices with the IT manager until the extent of the incident has
been quantified.
justifications.D:
An IS auditor should not develop policies.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is assessing services provided by an internet service provider (ISP)
during an IS compliance audit of a nationwide corporation that operates a governmental program. Which of
the following is MOST important?

options.A: Review the request fbr proposal.
options.B: Review monthly performance reports generated by the ISP.
options.C: Review the service level agreement (SLA).
options.D: Research other clients of the ISP.

Because the request for proposal is not the contracted agreement, it is more relevant to review the terms of
the service level agreement (SLA).
justifications.B:

justifications.C:
An SLA provides the basis for an adequate assessment of the degree to which the provider is

justifications.D: The services provided to other clients of the ISP are irrelevant to the information systems (IS) auditor.

questions.question:
During an audit of a small enterprise, the information systems (IS) auditor noted that the IS director has
superuser-privilege access that allows the director to process requests for changes to the application access
roles (access types). Which of the following should the IS auditor recommend?

options.A: Implement a properly documented process for application role change requests.
options.B: Hire additional staff to provide a separation of duties for application role changes.
options.C: Implement an automated process fbr changing application roles.
options.D: Document the current procedure in detail and make it available on the enterprise intranet.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor should recommend implementation of a process that can
prevent or detect improper changes from being made to the major application roles. The
application role change request process should start and be approved by the business owner; then,
the IS director can make the changes to the application.
justifications.B:
Although it is preferred that a strict separation of duties be adhered to and that additional staff
be recruited, this practice is not always possible in small enterprises. The IS auditor must look at
recommended alternative processes.
justifications.C:
An automated process fbr managing application roles may not be practical to prevent improper changes
being made by the IS director, who also has the most privileged access to the application.
justifications.D:
Making the existing process available on the enterprise intranet would not provide any value to protect the
system.

questions.question:
While observing a full simulation of the business continuity plan (BCP), an information systems (IS)
auditor notices that the notification systems within the organizational facilities can be severely impacted
by infrastructure damage. The BEST recommendation that the IS auditor can provide to the organization is to
ensure that:

options.A: the salvage team is trained to use the notification system.
options.B: the notification system provides fbr the recovery of the backup.
options.C: redundancies are built into the notification system.
options.D: the notification systems are stored in a vault.

justifications.A:
The salvage team would not be able to use a severely damaged notification system, even if they are
trained to use it.
justifications.B: The recovery of the backups has no bearing on the notification system.
justifications.C: If the notification system has been severely impacted by the damage, redundancy is the best control.
justifications.D: Storing the notification system in a vault is of little value if the building is damaged.

questions.question:
To ensure structured disaster recovery, it is MOST important that the business continuity plan (BCP) and
disaster recovery plan (DRP) are:

options.A: stored at an alternate location.
options.B: communicated to all users.
options.C: tested regularly.
options.D: updated regularly.

justifications.A:
Storing the business continuity plan (BCP) at an alternate location is useful in the case of complete site
outage; however, the BCP is not useful during a disaster without adequate tests.
justifications.B: Communicating to users is not of much use without actual tests.
justifications.C:
If the BCP is tested regularly, the BCP and disaster recovery plan (DRP) team are adequately
aware of the process and that helps in structured disaster recovery.
justifications.D:
Even if the plan is updated regularly, it is of less use during an actual disaster if it is not adequately tested.

questions.question: The PRIMARY purpose of a business impact analysis (BIA) is to:

options.A: define recovery strategies.
options.B: identify the alternate site.
options.C: improve recovery testing.
options.D: calculate the annual loss expectancy.

One of the primary outcomes of a business impact analysis (BIA) is the recovery time objective
(RTO)e and the recovery point objective (RPO), which help in defining the recovery strategies.
justifications.B:
A BIA, itself； does not help in identifying the alternate site. That is determined during the recovery
strategy phase of the project.
justifications.C:
A BIA, itself, does not help improve recovery testing. That is done during the implementation and testing
phase of the project.
justifications.D:
The annual loss expectancy of critical business assets and processes is determined during risk assessment
and is reviewed in the BIA, but this is not the primary advantage.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST helps define disaster recovery strategies?

options.A: Annual loss expectancy and exposure factor
options.B: Maximum tolerable downtime and data loss
options.C: Existing server and network redundancies
options.D: Data backup and oflfcite storage requirements

justifications.A: Annual loss expectancy and exposure factor are more related to risk in general.
justifications.B:
Two of the key outcomes of the business impact analysis are the recovery time objective (RTO) and
recovery point objective (RPO)—maximum tolerable downtime and data loss―that further help in
identifying the recovery strategies.
justifications.C:
Existing server and network redundancies are good to know, but the RTO and RPO are needed to design
the right recovery strategies.
justifications.D:

questions.question: After a disaster declaration, the media creation date at a warm recovery site is based on the:

options.A: recovery point objective (RPO)
options.B: recovery time objective (RTO)
options.C: service delivery objective (SDO)
options.D: maximum tolerable outage (MTO)

justifications.A:
The recovery point objective (RPO) defines the acceptable data loss in a disruption, indicating
the earliest acceptable data recovery point. It quantifies the permissible data loss in case of
interruption. The media creation date reflects the RPO for data restoration.
justifications.B:
The recovery time objective (RTO) is the amount of time allowed for the recovery of a business function
or resource after a disaster occurs.
justifications.C:
The service delivery objective (SDO) is directly related to the business needs and is the level of service to
be reached during the alternate process mode until the normal situation is restored.
justifications.D:
The maximum tolerable outage (MTO) is the maximum time that an organization can support processing
in alternate mode.

questions.question:
The activation of an enterprise's business continuity plan (BCP) should be based on predetermined criteria
that address the:

options.A: duration of the outage.
options.B: type of outage.
options.C: probability of the outage.
options.D: cause of the outage.

justifications.A:
The initiation of a business continuity plan (BCP) (action) should primarily be based on the
maximum period for which a business function can be disrupted before the disruption threatens the
achievement of organizational objectives.
justifications.B: The type of outage is not as important to the activation of the plan as the length or duration of the outage.
justifications.C:
The probability of the outage is relevant to the frequency of incidents, not the need to activate the plan.
The plan is designed to be activated after an event of a certain duration occurs.
justifications.D:
The cause of the outage may affect the response plan to be activated, but not the decision to activate the
plan. The plan will be activated any time an event of a predetermined duration occurs.
